list.item: ACT I . THE PLAYROOM . Ten days elapse .
ACT II . THE DRAWING-ROOM . Eight months elapse .
ACT III . GEORGIANA 'S ROOM . Four weeks elapse .

ACT IV . THE DRAWING-ROOM . PLACE — NEW YORK . THE PEOPLE IN THE PLAY GEORGIANA CARLEY . MRS. CARLEY Her step-mother . MRS. STEVEN CARLEY Her sister-in-law , born “ Coast , ” and daughter of Mrs. Carley by a former marriage . PHILIP } CHRISTOPHER } Children of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Carley . TOOTS } ELAINE From next door . LIZZIE Mrs. Carley 's maid . MISS BELLA SHINDLE “ The Lady Hair-dresser . ” LIEUTENANT RICHARD COLEMAN . SAM COAST Louise Carley 's own cousin . STEVEN CARLEY Georgiana 's brother . MOLES Butler to the Carleys . A FOOTMAN At the Carleys .

div.head: ACT I
div.stage: The nursery . Half-past two in the afternoon . A cool , delightful white room , with a frieze of children playing in the ocean spray ; shelves of bright-colored books on the walls , and the months of a large calendar by Elizabeth Shippen Green framed underneath . There is a deep bow-window at the back ; the principal door is at the Left , and a smaller one on the Right . Toys of all sizes , for all ages , are scattered about with a holiday air . There is a sofa on the Right and a hobby horse on the Left . There are four charming though somewhat spoiled children , with intermittent manners , with napkins tied up under their chins , sitting around the table , which is a little to the right of the centre of the room . The FOOTMAN is busy removing the plates ; the butler , MOLES , who stands behind PHILIP , always takes PHILIP 'S plate . It is PHILIP 'S birthday . LIZZIE stands behind ELAINE . In the centre of the table is a large cake with seven candles burning on it .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: What comes next ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Soup !

div.stage: LIZZIE and MOLES suppress smiles , exchanging looks of delighted appreciation of CHRISTOPHER 'S humor .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Ice cream !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Do n't be absurd , Christopher , we 've had soup .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: I like it !

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: I like ice cream !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: To TOOTS .Sh !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: What comes next , Moles ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: I do n't know , sir .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: T'ain ' t manners to ask , anyway , Phil .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Who cares ! It 's my birthday !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: When will it be my birthday ?

div.stage: The FOOTMAN reënters with plates , followed by MOLES , with silver dish of croquettes .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Here it comes ; what is it ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Chicken croquettes , sir .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Left overs ! Had chicken yesterday ! Bring ‘ em here first !

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: No , ladies first , sir .

div.stage: Serves ELAINE .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: And besides , Miss Elaine is company .

div.stage: MOLES serves CHRISTOPHER .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: That 's all right . S'long it 's Elaine , everything goes !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Phil !

div.stage: Sliding down from her chair , she runs to him and kisses him .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Hopelessly embarrassed .Do n't ! not in front of everybody !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: But I do love you , Phil , and you 're my beau , and I 'm so glad it 's your birthday .

div.stage: Goes back to her place unashamed and contented .
MOLES serves PHILIP .

lg.l: You ought n't to talk about beaux at your age , Miss — ought Miss
Elaine ?

div.stage: To MOLES with a knowing glance .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: I ai n't discussing the sex with you , Lizzie , but I will say all the girls I 've known , began talking about beaux early and ended late .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: I heard Lizzie and Moles talking about Aunt Georgiana 's beau !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Sh !

div.stage: FOOTMAN goes out with the croquette dish .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Mr. Dick Coleman 's Miss Carley 's beau !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , he is n't ! Mr. Dick 's known Aunt Georgiana always , they 're just little boy and girl friends . Lizzie says she 's Cousin Sammy Coast 's sweetheart .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Indignant , though convulsed .I never did !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , you did ! To Maggie when you thought I was n't paying attention .

div.stage: LIZZIE and MOLES exchange amused glances .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: But Mr. Coast 's your auntie 's cousin ; and your cousin can n't be your beau .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: He ai n't any relation to Auntie Georgiana . Mamma said so . Mr. Coast 's mamma 's cousin , and grandma 's nephew , but grandma is n't any real relation to auntie .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I do n't know how , only Aunt Georgiana had a different mamma , she did n't have grandma .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: And the same papa !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Not all the time , mamma had another papa first .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: It 's sort of mixy , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , I guess mamma and Aunt Georgy are sort of divorced sisters !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: As if that explained it .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Beating the table .Lemmlelade ! lemmlelade !

div.stage: MOLES crosses to pitcher and serves TOOTS first , then the others .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Toots , you 're getting tipsy !

div.stage: The children laugh .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Cousin Sammy comes to see Aunt Georgiana nearly every day .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes — he 's begun to bring toys just like some of the others did .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: With his mouth full .Hobby horse ! Hobby horse !

div.stage: Pointing to the hobby horse .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Do n't talk with your mouth full , Mr. Christopher .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shouting .He 'll choke ! He 'll choke !

div.stage: All laugh , tremendously amused .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Mr. Coast is a very fine gentleman .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , I know ! I saw him give you a dollar the other day , when he came to see auntie , and you advised his waiting and said auntie 'd be in by five .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Is n't he a case !

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: He certainly is .

div.stage: Returns pitcher to table on the Left .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: I like Mr. Dick best . He 's always taking us places and things .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Who has finished his croquette and is now ready for conversation .Um ! Circus !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: And not just ‘ cause he 's stuck on auntie .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: You ought n't to use that expression , Mr. Philip .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Why not ! you do . I heard you tell Lizzie you were stuck on her last Sunday .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Blushing .Oh , my !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Mr. Dick 's a soldier !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , siree ! He helped stop a strike of street cars in Brooklyn . His name was in the papers !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: He was hurted bad , and if he was dead , he 'd have a monnyment with “ Hero ” embroidered on it . Aunt Georgiana said so !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: I should think Miss Georgiana was too old , anyway , to have beaux .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Oh , awful old !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Oh ! Miss Carley is n't so old !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , she is , too ! She 's our old maid aunt .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: If she was n't old , she 'd be married . It must be awful to be so old .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: She 's nearly thirty , I guess .

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: Loud and long .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: You 'll be deader soon after thirty , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Crying .I do n't want Auntie Georgiana to be a deader !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bored .Shut up !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Comes to TOOTS and comforts him .Toots , dear !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I 'm glad Aunt Georgiana 's an old maid , ‘ cause I do n't want her to leave us .FOOTMAN enters and stands at the Right .She gave me my birthday party .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , and this whole house 'd miss your aunt , I can tell you that , Mr. Philip .Takes away the plates .She just keeps things going smooth with everybody .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I told her I saw you kiss Lizzie on the back stairs , Saturday .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: What !

div.stage: Gives dishes to the FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: He did n't ! He did n't !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , that 's what Aunt Georgiana said , but I know better , and so does she , I guess !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Is n't he a case !

div.stage: MOLES goes out with the FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Now what ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Soup !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ice cream ! I want ice cream !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Sh !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: My mamma do n't let my brothers behave so at the table .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Neither do n't we , ‘ cept our birthdays .

div.stage: MOLES reënters with a tray and plates .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Screams .Eeh ! Ice cream ! It 's ice cream !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Sh !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Go ahead , dish it out !

div.stage: Laughs .
MOLES serves ice cream to ELAINE , then to PHILIP , TOOTS , and CHRISTOPHER .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Mr. Dick Coleman is gooder as Cousin Sammy Coast .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Aunt Georgiana is goodest as him !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Aunt Georgiana is gooder as mamma !

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: And most goodest as grandma .

div.stage: LIZZIE exchanges a glance with MOLES and goes out Right .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Grandma ! Rats !

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: To PHILIP .Sh !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Shouts .Stop , Chris ! He 's taking too much ice cream !

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Chris ! Chris !

div.stage: They keep up the clamor , laughing and shouting , till LIZZIE comes back .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Children ! here comes grandma .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Disgusted .Oh , pshaw !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Do n't want grandma .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Sh !

div.stage: MRS. CARLEY comes in from the Right . She is a middle-aged woman , of faded prettiness and frivolous manner . Every line and bit of character has been massaged out of her face . There is a sudden , embarrassed , and gloomy silence on the part of the children .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Well , children , having a lovely party ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Grudgingly .Yes , ma'am !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Politely .Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Aunt Georgiana 's party !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , dear , it 's too bad mamma is ill in bed . She says when you are all through , you may come up and say how do you do , while she kisses Phil .Silence .That will be nice , wo n't it ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Grudgingly .Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: No !

lg.l: We are glad you could come in , Elaine , and help celebrate
Philip 's birthday .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Thank you , ma'am !

div.stage: TOOTS is mashing his ice cream strenuously with a spoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Toots ! do n't be naughty and do n't mash your ice cream up like that .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: I like it .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Me too — it makes soup !

div.stage: Copying TOOTS .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Your collar 's crooked , Chris .

div.stage: Arranging it .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Ouch !

div.stage: Squirming .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Phil , shall grandma cut your cake for you ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , ma'am , Auntie Georgiana 's going to cut it .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Oh , very well . How 's your mamma , Elaine ? Is she going to the big ball to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: We feel dreadfully . Philip 's mamma 's illness prevents our going .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Mamma said you were n't invited .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Pats PHILIP on the head , to his great disgust and discomfort .Your mamma had better mind ! Your mamma is mistaken ! Good-by , children , grandma is sorry she can n't stay and have a good time with you . I am going to call , Elaine , on the Countess of Worling , Mrs. Tom Cooley 's daughter . I do n't think your mother knows them . Good-by , dears , enjoy yourselves .

div.stage: She goes out Left .
Silence till the door is well shut behind grandma , and then the children break out with shouts , all of them , of “ Good-by , Grandma . Good-by , ” repeated ad lib . Then they calm down .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Bully ! Grandma 's gone !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Ice cream !

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: More ice cream ! Ice cream !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Let 's see .

div.stage: MOLES hands him the ice cream dish .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: To PHILIP .Can I have some more , or will it make me sick ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Serves the children .No , there 's plenty . When there is n't enough , mamma always says it will make us sick .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: And papa — when we have company unexpected , and there is n't enough of anything , papa always says F. H. B . PHILIP . F. H. B .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Why ?

lg.l: He says it means Family Hold Back , and we all have to say
“ No , thank you , ” when it comes around ! Do you like grandma , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Naw ! Grandma 's no good .

div.stage: MOLES goes out with the empty ice cream dish .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: No good , grandma !

div.stage: A knock outside the door Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Outside .Hello ! Hello !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Delighted .Aunt Georgiana !

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Aunt Georgiana !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Outside .Is this a private room at Sherry 's , or may an old maid aunt come in ?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: No ! Yes ! Come in — come on in !

div.stage: They clatter on the table with their spoons , and shout “ Hurrah ! Aunt Georgiana ! ” as GEORGIANA enters . She is a beautiful creature , about thirty , and in the very height of health and spirits — an American Beauty rose the moment before it opens . She is flushed after her quick walk in the bracing , sunshiny winter 's day . No wonder the children — and others — adore her !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What a good time !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Oh , we 're having the beautifulest time , Auntie !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Great !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Perfectly lovely !

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Um ! Ice cream ! Lots !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's good ! Stuff all you can , Toots ! Are you ready to cut the cake ?

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Yes ! Yes !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: We waited for you .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: We would n't let grandma .

div.stage: GEORGIANA drops her furs on the sofa and then comes to the table .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: There 's a ring in it . Whoever gets it will be married in a year .

div.stage: Starts to cut the cake .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: I want the ring !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Hush up , you 're only a baby !

div.stage: A loud knock on the door Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , yes , I forgot . Cousin Sam wants to wish you many happy returns , Philip . May he come in ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Pshaw ! Another man !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: In a “ stagewhisper ” to ELAINE .He 's the one — auntie 's sweetheart !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Amused .Nonsense , Christopher , that 's silly talk . Stop that for good !Loud knocks repeated . To PHILIP .May Cousin Sam come in ?PHILIP nods .All right , he 's got some presents ! Come in , Mr. Coast .

div.stage: COAST comes in and goes straight to PHILIP . SAM COAST is a tall , slender , but strong-looking man , rather “ raw-boned . ” He is dressed most fashionably and most expensively ,— over-dressed , in fact , and yet not too vulgarly . A man of muscle and nerve , who makes his own code and keeps his own counsel .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Shake , Phil .

div.stage: Shakes his hand .

lg.l: Golly ! He can squeeze , can n't he , Aunt
Georgiana ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , really ! Miss Elaine Jackson — Mr. Coast .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Embarrassed , rises , and curtseys .How do you do ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Pleased to make your acquaintance . Hello , rest of you . CHRISTOPHER and TOOTS . Hello !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Are you Auntie Georgiana 's beau ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Chris !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Lizzie says so !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: I never ! TOOTS , CHRISTOPHER , and PHILIP . Yes , you did ! You did too ! You did too !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: To GEORGIANA .I never did , miss !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes you did , you did too !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I hope you did n't , Lizzie . You may leave the children with me now .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

div.stage: LIZZIE , MOLES , and FOOTMAN go out at Right , each taking some plates , etc .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: To COAST .I hope you do n't mind .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Of course I do n't . It 's true as far as I 'm concerned .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughing .It 's not !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen , will you bet ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughing .Not before the children !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Come on , let 's cut the cake !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Blow out the candles !

div.stage: All the children blow out the candles and then get down from the table .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And here 's my contribution to the party .

div.stage: Brings out six big German mottoes from his pocket , and goes to table with them .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: In pretended excitement .What ? Mottoes !

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: In delighted chorus .Oh , mottoes !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Are those the silver mines ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No ! Why ?

div.stage: Laughing and handing the mottoes around , while GEORGIANA cuts the cake .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I heard grandma say the other day , you had pockets full of silver mines .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: The cake 's ready !

div.stage: All take a piece of cake . The children line up and down Centre from Right to Left : ELAINE , TOOTS , PHILIP , CHRISTOPHER .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Your motto !

div.stage: Handing one to GEORGIANA .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: One for me too ! Oh , thank you !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Certainly , because I want a bit of cake . I 'm after that ring .

div.stage: Goes up back of table for cake .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't anybody swallow the ring .

div.stage: All eat the cake and now speak with their mouths full .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: I have n't got it yet , Auntie .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Nor I .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't talk . Everybody eat till some one gets it !

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Crying .I can n't eat my cake ! I can n't eat my cake !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why not , dear ?

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: ‘ Cause I have n't got no place ! I have n't got no place to put it !

div.stage: Crying .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: He 's full up !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Never mind , Toots , dear , you shall have a piece for supper .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Will I have room then ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: A sudden loud and frightened cry .Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

div.stage: All gather around CHRISTOPHER .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Frightened .What is it , Chris ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Screaming .Oh !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What is it , dear ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: I 've swallowed it !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: I 've swallowed the ring !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: That is n't fair !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Just like Chris , ‘ fraid some one else 'd get it .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , Chris , dear !To COAST .What will we do ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Chris has made a mistake , here is the ring !Finding it in his own piece of cake .There were n't two , were there ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , that 's the one !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Smiling and greatly relieved .Oh ! I guess I ‘ magined it , then .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Affectionately pretending to shake him .Well , young man , you can imagine yourself spanked for giving us all a fright . Now , come along , the mottoes .To COAST .Of course the ring was n't meant for you . What are you going to do with it ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Keep it .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , you must n't ; it 's the children 's !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Philip , may I keep the ring ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: On the hobby horse .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And I 'll give each one of you a ring in place of it . What kind will you have , Elaine ?

div.stage: He makes movement towards each child as he asks the question .

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: One big pearl with two great big rubies .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mercy ! Small order !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Very well . And you , Phil ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I do n't want any ring . I want a watch and chain .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Good ! And you , Chris , do you want a ring ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: I want a gun !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: All right .Writing .And Toots ?

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Nanny goat !

div.stage: They all laugh . MOLES and FOOTMAN enter , answering the bell which GEORGIANA has rung .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: The table , Moles .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

div.stage: Takes away small plates , etc . ; he then goes out Right , followed by FOOTMAN , who takes everything else from the table , leaving only the cover and a false nose left from the mottoes .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Crosses to GEORGIANA at table .Grandma 's been up and said we were all to go and see mamma .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Go in your mottoes ; that will be great fun !

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Oh , yes ! Hurrah !

div.stage: Running off Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Ssh ! Do n't shout so ; remember poor mamma 's headache !

div.stage: All repeat , “ Remember poor mamma 's headache ” and take hands as they tip-toe out , PHILIP first , ELAINE second , CHRIS third , TOOTS fourth , repeating “ Poor mamma 's headache ” in a whisper till they are all out .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I can n't get this damned thing on . Too bad Cousin Loo 's ill .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , she is n't really . Louise is never perfectly well and happy unless she has something the matter with her , especially if she has nothing else to do ; she 's bored to-day , so she 's got a headache ! To-night , when there 's a big ball to which she is not invited , she 'll be frightfully alarmed about herself for fear of appendicitis , but to-morrow , when we have smart company at luncheon , she 'll recover like a shot ! It 's all right for Louise , but it 's hard on my brother , who really adores her .

div.stage: She sits beside the table .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Adores ! Say ! That 's the word I want to use about you !

div.stage: Follows GEORGIANA to table , moves chair to front , and sits .

lg.l: Nonsense , Sam ! Do you know anything about some stocks called
United Copper ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Rotten ! Do n't touch it !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: My brother had a tip this morning on United Copper and wanted me to give him some money to put in it .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen ! do n't you do it .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I wish you 'd use your influence with Steven to help him .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You must know how mad he is over speculation ? But perhaps you do n't know that he has gone through all his own money , and , if she 'll let him , he 'll go through his wife 's next .Smiling .Then I suppose it would be my turn !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why does n't he keep out of it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: He can n't , we must keep it out of him ! Out of his blood !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: There 's only one way .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Ruin him !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's too anarchistic ! You speculate .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: But I always win !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Ca n't you teach him ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen , if I could do that , I 'd be the richest man in the world before I got through .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Ca n't you give Steve a tip on some sure things ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: There ai n't any sure things .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why , other friends of Steve are always “ putting him on to something good . ”

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And what happens ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Smiling distressfully .Well , he does lose , usually .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I guess so !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But you must often have inside information .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And how much is that worth ?

div.stage: Takes up the false nose from table .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , it usually costs Steve all he has ! But I thought you —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Interrupting .Miss Georgiana , you see this false nose ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Putting it on .Well , now what do I look like ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughing .I should n't like to say !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Exactly ! Well , see ? That 's what I 'd be if I believed in tips and “ inside information . ” If a man gives your brother a good tip , let him drop it like hot lead . People with a real good tip ai n't giving it away . There 's never enough to divide up and go around ,— not in this world ,— and inside information that gets told to a lamb like your brother is too damned outside information for me !

div.stage: He rises and moves away , half in irritation , half in humor .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Pardon .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Are you as rich as people say ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Richer !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: How did you get it ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I started my dough with a mine .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why can n't you put Steve into a mine ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Laughing .What 's the use ? he 'll lose everything just as quick in Wall Street .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But I mean a good mine .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Coming back to her .Listen ! I worked right in our mine with my father when I was only eight years old ! That 's why I ai n't better educated — I worked for ten years there down in the dirt and muck !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Interrupting .And silver !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Leaning on the back of the chair .Yes , and silver .Laughs .Father 's out there working yet — do n't have to now , but he likes it ; he ai n't comfortable on top of the earth — says there 's too much room . If father 'd been a man like Mackay , I guess he 'd been just as rich as him to-day .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And still you wo n't help Steve ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: T'ain ' t business .He puts back his chair and leans toward GEORGIANA , hand on table .If helping him , mind you , would get you , I might take it on .Humorously .I 'd pay even the price of Steve to buy you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Taking the false nose and putting it on .Well , I 'm not for sale .Rises .But I would like to dispose of Steven .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Go on , please take that blame thing off .

div.stage: Follows GEORGIANA across the room to the Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , I like it ! You must understand this about my brother .Taking off the nose .He is the dearest , best fellow in the world ! kind-hearted and would n't do a thing that was n't straightforward in business .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: But you 've got to be tricky if you want to succeed in our business . I do n't mind telling you right out between us , I 'm tricky !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I 'm sorry to hear it .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Louise was a pretty good liar when she was a kid . She ought to help her husband along a little .

lg.l: That 's just it ! if Steve had the right sort of wife ,— but all
Louise wants is social position and more money .

div.stage: She sits on the hobby horse , amusedly .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: If Louise was like you !

div.stage: GEORGIANA puts the nose on quickly and rocks .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Heaven forbid ! The only trouble with Steve is he 's weak . He 'd have been all right if he 'd been a girl — or married to a president of Sorosis , or a daughter of the Present Revolution !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Miss Georgiana , take off that nose and let me ask you something .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Not at all , my dear Sammy . I know what it is you want to ask me ! I 'm much obliged and I wo n't .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: You wo n't marry me !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Because I do n't love you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Who do you love ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's not your business !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do you love any one ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: After a moment 's hesitation , lies .No !

lg.l: Why do n't you get Dick Coleman to help
Steven ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Taking off the nose .Why do you ask me that now in that way ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Information !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Dick 's a lawyer . What could he do for Steven ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That 's not the information I wanted .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But it 's all the information you 'll get !

div.stage: Gets off the hobby horse and comes down a little .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Follows her .Georgiana , marry me , and I 'll look after Steven all the rest of his life .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sammy , you do n't want me to marry you if I do n't love you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes , I do . Listen ! I 'd risk your not loving me ; there 's nothing on God 's earth I would n't do to make you love me .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's the trouble with you men , you think you can make a woman love you whether she wants to or not , but you can n't !— neither can you keep her from loving you if she does , whether she wants to or not .

div.stage: Throws nose away ; crossing to the Left , sits in the rocking chair there .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'd give you everything !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That you can buy !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do you mean that you 'd rather be dead poor than marry me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , I do n't say that ! When I 've lost everything and Steven and Louise are bankrupt , and we have n't a penny —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I might — I say I might —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Honest !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughing .Oh , dear , no !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I take you at your word , anyhow .

div.stage: The children 's voices are heard .

sp.speaker: CHILDREN
sp.p: Off Left .Come on back to our room and have some more fun .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sh ! Here come the children .

div.stage: Rises .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Damn the children !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sam !

div.stage: She puts finger up , COAST kisses it .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Pardon ! But I do n't give up ! Understand — I 'm going to marry you !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Teasing him .When ? When ?

div.stage: The children rush in screaming .

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Aunt Georgiana ! Here 's papa ! Here 's papa !

div.stage: And STEVEN CARLEY enters Left . He is a slender , smooth-shaven , young-old looking man , his voice and body almost vibrating with nerve ; a personality that so often appeals to the tenderness in women , while it irritates men . He brings his hat and coat with him .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Hello , Sam !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Morning !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Many happy returns , Georgy .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , no , thank you ! It 's not for me yet , thank goodness !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Now let 's play hide and seek .

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Hide and seek !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Entering Left .Excuse me , please . Mrs. Jackson 's maid is here for Miss Elaine .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , pshaw !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Do n't you go !

sp.speaker: ELAINE
sp.p: Oh , yes , I must ! I 'm sorry !She goes up stage with great diffidence to STEVEN and shakes his hand as she curtseys .Good-by , sir .To COAST also .Good-by , sir .To GEORGIANA .Good-by , ma'am , I 've had a perfectly lovely time .Aside to GEORGIANA .Phil is my beau , but I like Mr. Coast awfully much too !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughing .You 're beginning early ! Come along , children , we 'll take Elaine down . Excuse me , everybody , please .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: If you 've got any good tips , papa , save some for little brother .

div.stage: The children go out Left with GEORGIANA .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Putting his hat and coat down on the sofa .He 's on to his father early ! Sam , any news ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 've heard of a big thing , an absolutely straight tip ,— inside information .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Sitting in the rocker .Well , do n't tell it , or you 'll spoil it .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: The women are so down on my speculating , Georgiana especially .

div.stage: Sits on the table .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What do the women folks know about business ? Why do n't you keep what you do to yourself ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But you see my money 's all gone , and I need more — only to recoup with .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: After a slight pause .As I remember , you can do what you like with Louise 's money .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But is it right ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: You 're too blamed afraid , that 's why you always lose .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Walking up and down .I know it . And this is the biggest chance I 've had yet . If I dared risk it , I 'm sure I could make a fortune ! Not in words ! I know what I 'm talking about , Sam . Louise would have everything she wanted — and the way she 'd live then ! She could drop the social chip off her shoulders , go anywhere , and receive everybody .

div.stage: Standing beside the table , he eats a little cake .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Do you advise me to risk it ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Pretending indifference .What ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Louise 's money ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I ai n't advising anything . If it went wrong , you 'd blame me to the women .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Is that the kind of a man I am ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Rises and goes to Steven and slaps him on the back .No , Steve , I take it back . You take a licking better'n any feller I ever saw .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Experience ! But this thing can n't go wrong ! The man who told me is the head and — I told Georgiana — did n't she give you a hint ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: After a slight pause .No .

div.stage: Turns up to the window and stands there with his back to Steven .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: My tip 's a great one — safe ! Now , shall I take it ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Of course , when I feel as you do about a thing , I do it .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: And by George , I will too !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why not ?

div.stage: Turning and facing him .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes ! what I make 's for Louise , not for myself .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I would n't say anything to Louise about it .

div.stage: Comes down a little .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: No , she 'd be sure to talk it over with Georgiana .

div.stage: He sits by the table .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And , say , not a word , you know , about me in all this .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I give you my word , Sam .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why not let the old lady in , too , Aunt Laura , if it 's such a good thing ?

div.stage: He gives a side look at STEVEN .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Did n't they tell you ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I put mother into East Mexicos !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Gee !

div.stage: Whistles , crosses to the sofa Right , and sits on GEORGIANA 'S furs ; jumps up quickly , moves the furs , and then sits again .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: That was an extraordinary thing . No one knows how it happened , but she lost every cent .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Dear old Georgiana pays the interest for me , and the old lady does n't know .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Georgiana 's a damn fine girl .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: She is ! I 'll pay her back out of this coup , too , another good thing .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Fine !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I believe I 'll go back down town now .

div.stage: Both rise and go Left as MOLES comes in .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: All right . Come on , we 'll go together .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Good !

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Please , sir , may I speak to you a minute , Mr. Carley ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'll wait downstairs , Steve .

div.stage: He goes out Left .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , Moles ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: The champagne is out , sir .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Order another case .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: I did , three days ago , over the telephone , and I called them up yesterday to ask about it , and they said your bill was so long outstanding they 'd please like it settled before filling any future orders .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Tell Mrs. Carley ; the household bills are her affair , are n't they ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: She says there is some mistake . She gave you a check for the wine bill last month , sir .

lg.l: Did she ? Oh , of course she did . It was the day I heard about
Alabama Rails and I bought a couple on margin ! They 're down just now .
The wine people must wait .

div.stage: Dismissing him .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: But we 've a big luncheon , sir , to-morrow and no wine .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Very well , then , I 'll get Miss Georgiana to give you a check . I do n't want to bother Mrs. Carley , she 's got a headache .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: The wages are due , sir , and the trades books were n't settled last month .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Well , I 'll attend to it all to-morrow or next day , Moles . Give me my coat , will you ?MOLES gets the coat from the sofa and hands it to STEVEN .I 've been short of ready money for a little while , but things are looking up . By the way , you 're a good sort ; I 'd like to do you a good turn . I happen to be on to something , Moles , on to something down in Wall Street . Would you like to make a little money ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Brightening visibly .Indeed and I would , sir . I 've got two thousand three hundred and sixteen dollars in my savings bank , and I 've heard of how these Wall Street magnums made fortunes out of less'n that .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'll double it for you ! You get it for me , Moles , and I 'll make it into five or six thousand for you , sure !

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Thank you , sir !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Writes in note book .I 'll put in an order to buy for you the first thing in the morning ; and you have your money down at my office by ten o'clock , can you ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , sir , I can get off in the morning . I can n't thank you enough , sir !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right ,— we 'll be a rich household here before we get through , Moles . They 'll be telephoning us to please send in some orders for champagne !

div.stage: Puts note-book away .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Oh , do n't trouble about these bills , sir . I can hold off the people a little longer , and I 'll order the wine in another place .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: That 's a good boy , Moles , then I wo n't have to bother my sister .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: He goes out as GEORGIANA and the children enter Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Here 's papa ! Come along , now , Steve , I 've promised the children a game of hide and go seek !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: All right , I knew father wanted to do something very much ,— only could n't think what . Of course , it was hide and seek !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Philip must be “ it ” first !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: All right !

div.stage: PHILIP goes into the corner Right , with his back to the others . All hide behind or under the different pieces of furniture — GEORGIANA under the table , TOOTS back of the rocker , STEVEN under the sofa , etc .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Impatient .Are you ready ?

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Not yet !

div.stage: Getting behind curtains Centre window .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Now are you ready ?

div.stage: LIZZIE comes in Left , as soon as STEVEN hides under sofa .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Not yet !

div.stage: Getting under the table .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Mr. Carley , please , sir !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Putting his head out from under the sofa .Yes , Lizzie ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Do n't turn round , Phil , it 's only Lizzie . Wait !

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Excuse me , but Mr. Coast sent me upstairs to see —

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , by George , yes !Coming out from the sofa .I forgot . I must go back down town .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , pshaw !

div.stage: About to turn .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't turn , Phil !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: No , the rest of us is hid !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'm sorry , children ! Father 'd a great deal rather play hide and seek , but he 's got to go to work . It 's just like when you 'd rather play but have to study !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: When I get growed , I sha n't never do anything I do n't want to .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Then you 'd be the most wonderful person in the world , and they 'd put you in wax in the Eden Musée !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Kissing PHIL , then CHRIS , then TOOTS .Good-by , dears .

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Dolefully .Good-by .

div.stage: STEVEN crosses to the door Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Never mind , I 'll finish with you . Do n't turn around , Phil .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: At the door Left .Beg pardon , sir , but Moles has been and told me what you was going to do for him , sir . Would you be considering it great impertinence if I asked you to take six hundred dollars what I 've saved , sir , and do things with it ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Certainly , Lizzie , send it by Moles in the morning .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Delighted .Oh , thank you , sir !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'm glad to do it ; you 've served us faithfully for some years now , Lizzie .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: He 's gone , miss .

div.stage: She goes out also .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Calls .Ready !

div.stage: PHILIP turns and looks about the room , then begins to look under things . He sees his AUNT GEORGIANA first and is about to touch her , but she laughingly motions him not to and points out TOOTS 'S hiding place .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Finding TOOTS , touches him .You 're it !

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Very pleased .I 'm it ! I 'm it !

div.stage: Jumps up and down .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Disappointed .Somebody find me .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , come on out from behind the curtain — you 're — easy .

div.stage: CHRISTOPHER comes out . Meanwhile COLEMAN is heard calling , “ Hello , Phil , Phil , ” outside as he comes up the stairs .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: By the hobby horse .It 's Mr. Dick !

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: It 's Mr. Dick !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: Starts to get out from under the table , but COLEMAN enters , so she crawls back .

LIEUTENANT RICHARD COLEMAN is a handsome , finely built man of about thirty-two . He is a West Pointer , is a good oarsman , a crack shot , and a good fellow all around . No finicking about him , no nerves . Just a sane , healthy , fine fellow .

lg.l: Hello ! Many happy returns , Phil .
Where 's your
Aunt Georgiana !
Is she out ?

sp.speaker: PHIL
sp.p: No , she 's under the table !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER AND TOOTS
sp.p: Delighted .She 's under the table ! She 's under the table !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Laughing .What !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Hide and seek .

div.stage: DICK looks under the table ; he and GEORGIANA laugh .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Good morning , are you at home ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Very embarrassed .Oh , mercy ! Do go away so I can get out !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Tremendously amused .Come on out !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ! I can n't with you there .Laughing .Please leave the room for just one minute !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Not if I know it ! Come on out !

lg.l: Not for worlds ! Go away , please !
Then I shall never come out .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Ah , but that 's hardly fair , because I want to talk to you comfortably .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , then , come on under !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Is there room ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: A cable car conductor who knew his business could seat four more people in here .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Still — I think I 'm more comfortable up here .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Selfish ! Go on away !DICK shakes his head .Children , if you love your auntie , go for Mr. Dick with all your might and main and push him into the hall .

div.stage: The children shout and rush toward DICK ; they catch hold of him .

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Go away !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: With mock ferocity .The first child I get hold of I 'll spank !

div.stage: The children laugh and shout and run away from him to behind the table .

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Spank !

lg.l: Ogre ! Very well ! After all , I 'm not vain ! It would take
Barnum 's human snake to get out of this gracefully , anyway !

div.stage: Coming out , arranging her dress and hair .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Have some help ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , thank you . But still , what a horrid person you are , are n't you ?

div.stage: They both laugh .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You are n't !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: O dear me ! Making up now with a compliment ! Well , what do you think of my birthday antics ? Playing hide and seek — or , perhaps , trained elephants — does n't interest you !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Lelephants ! Oh , Auntie ! Is the circus coming ?

div.stage: The children give themselves up to transports . PHIL hugs TOOTS and repeats “ Circus . ”

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , darling , but this circus is going — your old-maid aunt — to put herself to rights !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You could n't improve on present appearances !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Really ! Such fine speeches ! But they do n't go with your manners ! Would you like to join in the game ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , yes ! Hurrah !

div.stage: Runs to DICK , when MRS. CARLEY comes in from the Left .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Well ! What 's going on ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Birthdays !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Not for me !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't you want to play hide and go seek , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I 'm playing it all the time with old age ! That 's enough !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , excuse me , please , while I repair damages .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Calls .Come back .

sp.speaker: CHILDREN
sp.p: Calling .Come back !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I want the children for a few minutes .

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Disappointed .Oh , Grannie !

div.stage: She goes to children and drives them off Left ahead of her .

sp.speaker: THE CHILDREN
sp.p: Oh , Grandma !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Mrs. Vale is downstairs with the twins , to wish Phil many happy returns .

div.stage: The children go out Left unwillingly . MRS. CARLEY comes back .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Going to spoil our game , Grandma ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Do n't you grandma me ! You 're old enough for me to marry you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Help !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Do n't worry ! Having lost two good husbands , I 'm not going to risk losing a third .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I breathe freely once more .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I thought Sammy Coast was here .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Not since I came . He seems a clever chap !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: We think so , and we hope so . He adores Georgiana .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Huh ! huh !DICK walks away .What do you say to that match ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You do n't mean ?—

div.stage: Turns to MRS. CARLEY .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Looks like it ! It would be a fine thing for both of them . Sam could give her a fortune , and Georgiana give him a big position .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: He 's crazy about her ! Comes here every day — follows her like a dog .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: But it is n't —

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Interrupting .Not yet , but we do n't dare breathe ! And we 're on tiptoe for the final word .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What does Steven say ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Delighted , of course .Walks away a little .I hope you have n't brought Steve any tips to-day .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Laughing .No !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Thank goodness ! He does n't seem to have had any this week and the house has been fairly quiet !GEORGIANA comes back .I must go to Mrs. Vale .Goes out .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mother looks pleased .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: She 's never very depressed , is she ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , sometimes ,— in the day-time ! It 's largely a matter of frocks and bonnets , and depends sometimes on the exact color of her hair .

lg.l: I often wonder that you keep on living with Mrs. Carley and
Louise . They can n't help being beastly uncongenial to you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But Mrs. Carley brought me up . She did her worst with the best intentions , and you must n't forget Steve !She sits beside the table and DICK leans against it to talk to her .He 's my own brother , you know , and I 'm so afraid Louise will finally disillusion him and spoil his happiness . I 'm standing on guard .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You think a lot of Steve .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I love him better than any one else in the world .She adds in a very low voice .Almost !

div.stage: A short pause .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Steve comes second !

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Low voice and looking away .Perhaps .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I hope you do n't mind my asking you these questions .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , I like it .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I do n't want you to tell me anything more than you care to .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Turning and half laughing .That 's very good of you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: But I wish you 'd tell me everything .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: My dear Dick , there is n't anything more for me to tell .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh , very well , if you want to leave it that way .

div.stage: Moving away .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Leave what ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I mean if that 's all you want to tell me .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why do n't you tell me something .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: That 's what I 've come to do .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Have you ?

lg.l: Our regiment is ordered off to the
Philippines .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Your regiment ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Breathless .Who 's going ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Who ? Why , we 're going , of course .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: All of you ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes , all of us . There are two insurrections on a couple of islands that must be put down , and they want some fresh men .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But it will be awful warfare out there , wo n't it , unfair , cruel , unlawful warfare ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I suppose that 's what it 's likely to be with the natives until we teach them a thorough lesson on every one of the infernal islands .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But —

div.stage: Hesitates , rises ; they are both in front of the table .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: But what ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Pause .But your business ,— how can you leave your office ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: There are plenty of people who 'll be only too glad to take on my clients .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But when you come back ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: If the worst comes to the worst , I 'll have to begin all over again .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ! Do n't go — Dick ! Do n't go !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Humorously , to cover her emotion .I do n't want any one else to get your clients .

lg.l: Oh , you were thinking of my career ! That 'll take care of itself if
I come back — and if I do n't —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Please !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: They said we were a lot of dandies in the regiment , and that if it ever came to fighting , people 'd see us back down !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But need you all go ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: That 's the glory of it ! It 's fine , Georgy . There is n't a single man who 'll be left behind , not on any old excuse !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Splendid !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You do want me to go , then , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , if it 's like that , I want you to go — but — I want you to come back , too !

div.stage: Almost breaking down .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Hello ! I believe you 're crying .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I 'm not !

lg.l: Do you care so much as that ,
Georgy ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Proudly .Of course I care !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's funny , is n't it — think how long we 've known each other .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Still with a choke and a tear .I do n't see why it 's funny .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What I mean is , we 're sentimental beasts — we people .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Thank you , I do n't care for the way you put it .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Takes a long breath .Well , I wish you joy , Georgiana .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Much obliged .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And good-by .

div.stage: Shakes hands .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Rises .Not now , for good .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Laughing .Oh , no , we are n't off for ten days yet . But I wanted to tell my old pal first .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That was good of you . And you 'll come in often before you go , wo n't you , Dick ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You bet ! Every chance I get .

div.stage: Both go up to the window . He has meant to go , but she manoeuvres him to the big seat instead .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And anything I can do for you ?

div.stage: She sits .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Sitting beside her .Oh , I do n't think there can be anything .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , yes , there is always something women can do for men who go away to fight . They make things ! Let me make something for you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Ca n't think of anything . Got everything I want .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You 're a lucky man to have everything you want — and going off to the Philippines with a jolly crowd of friends and glad you 're going ! I take back all my sympathy , and I would n't make you anything now if you asked me to .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And , by George , just when I 'd thought of something .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Laughing .A court-plaster case !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You can buy one in a drug store .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I ought to have some present to carry in my breast pocket ; do n't you know bullets are always warded off that way ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , that was in the old romantic days of the nineteenth century , and then it was a prayer book or a bunch of love letters . To-day it 's much more apt to be a cigarette case !

div.stage: The children run in , led by PHILIP .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: They 've gone ! Hurrah ! They 've gone !

div.stage: GEORGIANA and DICK rise .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: They 've gone ! They 've gone !

div.stage: TOOTS hangs on to DICK .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Taking hold of GEORGIANA .Come on , now , our game , or we 'll never have it !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Blindman 's buff !

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Yes , blindman 's buff !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: To DICK .Are you game ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Just one round , and then I must be off . I 'll be blindfolded .

div.stage: Takes out his handkerchief .

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: I want to be blindfolded !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No ! Let Mr. Dick !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Giving his handkerchief to GEORGIANA .Will you blindfold me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Binds his eyes .To my faults ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: That would be Love 's Labour Lost .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: How do you mean Love 's Labour Lost ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Do n't let him peek !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: And whoever I catch , I kiss !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , tell the name first !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No , I must play my own game , and that is to kiss her first , and tell the name afterwards !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Now , turn him around three times , Christopher .CHRISTOPHER does so , holding DICK by the knees .And keep away , everybody !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Ready !

div.stage: All watch eagerly . DICK moves down stage , reaching his arms out as a blindfolded person does , but always with his arms too high to catch one of the children .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Put your arms lower !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Yes , you can only catch Aunt Georgiana that way !

div.stage: GEORGIANA , happy , pinches CHRISTOPHER 'S arm playfully . DICK lowers his arms for a moment , but purposely catches no one . Then he lifts his arms a little towards GEORGIANA , who cries out and moves , lifting TOOTS on the table . DICK follows the sound of her voice and catches hold of TOOTS 'S head .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Excited .Mus n't move your hands !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Make her kiss me , then .

div.stage: GEORGIANA leans over , holding TOOTS to one side , and kisses DICK herself .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Delighted , calls out .Guess who ! Guess who !

div.stage: GEORGIANA motions to the children not to tell and moves away .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Hearing the voice from where he supposes the kiss came , he lakes off the bandage . He sees TOOTS and is disappointed .Why — I thought it was Georgiana ! Toots ! You rascal !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: Trying to tell .But Mr. Dick , Mr. Dick !

div.stage: TOOTS laughs and claps hands . GEORGIANA gets hold of CHRISTOPHER and holds her hand over his mouth . GEORGIANA and CHRISTOPHER follow DICK to the door Left .

lg.stage: To CHRISTOPHER , to stop his telling .
lg.l: Sh !
Good-by !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Good-by !

sp.speaker: TOOTS
sp.p: Wanting to tell .But —

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Good-by ! Good-by !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good-by Dick ! Come soon again !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: To-morrow !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I 'll wait in all day !

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: But Mr. Dick , it was —

div.stage: GEORGIANA hushes him with her hand over his mouth .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good-by !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Good-by !

div.stage: He goes out Left .
CHRISTOPHER , PHILIP , AND TOOTS . Good-by !
GEORGIANA bursts into tears and hugs TOOTS on top of the table .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: But it was you , Aunt Georgiana !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't any of you tell on auntie ! You wo n't , will you ? Let auntie have her own way . THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: The drawing-room at the Carleys ’ . A handsome room in dark wood , with tapestry on the walls and an old portrait built in over the mantle . The furniture is gilt , Louis XVI , covered with old crimson brocade . There is a warmth about the room , a profusion of flowers , some books and magazines . A piano in the upper left-hand corner , a window with a balcony at Left . Doors Right and Left . LOUISE and MRS. CARLEY are replacing the furniture , which has been disarranged . Out on the balcony MOLES is seen , with PHILIP and CHRISTOPHER , arranging an American flag on the balcony balustrade .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Thank goodness , the luncheon 's over !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , I thought they 'd never go , and I 've got the Shindle woman coming to do my hair .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I noticed it was getting a little dark at the wrong end , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: What was it Steve said this morning ? It was always darkest before blond ! Well , it 's lucky I 'm good-natured so long as I live in this family and do n't want to grow old .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: What are they doing on the balcony ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Dick Coleman 's regiment marches by here this afternoon .

div.stage: She sits by a table Right .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Do they start for the Philippines to-day ?

lg.l: Yes , and the President is to receive them in front of the
Plaza .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Coming to her .Have you noticed Steve ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: No ,— has he got a new suit ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No , something 's troubling him .Thoughtfully .I believe he 's been speculating again and has lost .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: He could n't ; he has n't got anything more to lose .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Petulantly .He has n't played with the children for a week and he hates going out so lately ,— wants to refuse every invitation ! Even the ones you and I 've been patting ourselves on the back for getting ! I can n't stand it .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Quite right , too — if one does n't go out , where can one go , and if we do n't go anywhere , what are we to do ? We can n't stay home .Rising , she crosses to mirror on table Left .I say , dear , what about having my hair a little redder ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Let me see !MRS. CARLEY faces her — LOUISE examines her critically .I would n't much ; if you do , people will say you dye it .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I do n't care what they say , so long as they do n't say it to my face . Have you had yours massaged this morning ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes , why ?

div.stage: Goes to mirror and , pushing MRS. CARLEY out of the way , examines her face in the glass .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Nothing , only I think you must have it done religiously , darling ; the crow 's feet are beginning to come .

div.stage: Sits on sofa and begins to crochet on an afghan .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Oh , I 'm worried to-day and besides , I think our masseuse is getting careless .Turns , goes up to MRS. CARLEY , and sits on the sofa .I 'm going to change her ; she never tells you anything about anybody , anyway .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I told you that the first day she came . She was positively rude the way she refused to be pumped by me about the people next door . Do you know I 'm worried too .Rises , gives LOUISE her work , and again looks in the glass .I think my hips are getting bigger .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Well , my dear mother , you must have hips sometime in your life , and you 've done pretty well . Look at your friend , Mrs. Brint .

div.stage: FOOTMAN enters with tray , goes to table Right , and collects the small cups and saucers .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: My dear ! when Sarah Brint was married she looked like a widow !LOUISE laughs .It made me so mad seeing the people eat everything the way they did .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Mamma , you 're so amusing . Of course we do have good food ; we must get people here somehow .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: And I not daring to eat a thing ! Why is it nice things are all fattening ?

div.stage: The FOOTMAN goes out .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Rises and comes to MRS. CARLEY .Does it strike you that this dress of mine makes me look too short-waisted ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Turn round .LOUISE does so .Yes ! do n't wear it again .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Irritated .Why did n't you tell me before lunch ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I did n't notice it !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Angry . Turns to mirror and then to MRS. CARLEY .That 's just it ! You do n't care ! You do n't think of me ever ! You only think of yourself !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Angry .That 's not true . I 've sacrificed my life for you , and for what good ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: What good ! Good heavens , have n't Steve and I done everything for you , lugged you into the best position almost in New York ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , that 's just it , “ almost ! ” Your husband hates me and you back him up — and keep me in the background !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I could n't ! You would n't stay there .

div.stage: With a disagreeable laugh .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Sits in chair left of the table .That 's it , insult me ,— but I 've had enough ! I 've made up my mind , anyway , to leave your house and live by myself .

div.stage: Whimpering .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Oh , stop , mamma . You know I did n't mean anything . I 'm sorry !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Crying .No , I 'm in the way .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: You 're not in the way . You know I could n't live without my darling pretty little mamma . Please stop crying and kiss me .

div.stage: Puts her arms around her .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Still crying .I have n't anybody in the world but you .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Do n't I know that , do n't I know I could n't get on without you ! There !Kisses her .Now it 's all right . Come on , darling , come up and get your hair dyed .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Pleasantly .Sh ! do n't call it that !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I am irritable lately , I know it — but I see without our money even Steve could n't get us a decent position . We might just as well face the truth . Certain people do n't appreciate you and me , mamma . We are n't even acquired tastes .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: No one ever appreciated me long . I was prettier than you were at your age , and my husbands both fell in love with me at first sight . But I never wore well .

div.stage: She takes a magazine from the table and begins to cut the pages .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I wonder if Georgiana will marry Sammy !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I wish to goodness she would .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I believe she 's in love with Mr. Coleman .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: No , they 've always known each other .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Well , some people wear better than we do , that 's all ! and I believe she 's in love with him , whether either of them know it or not .

div.stage: GEORGIANA comes in Left with BELLA SHINDLE . MISS SHINDLE is a florid , buxom young person , pleased with herself and all the world . She carries several packages .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Here 's Bella , mother .

sp.speaker: EVERYBODY
sp.p: How are you , Bella ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: All your guests gone ?

div.stage: She sits left of table . MRS. CARLEY goes back of table , and LOUISE moves to the right .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , thank goodness ! You might have been here .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You know I can n't stand your would-be smart parties !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I think they 're always angry when they do n't see you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Nonsense ! Did you have a good time ? Pick everybody else to pieces ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No , we all said nice things about Mrs. Lothman .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mercy ! What 's the matter with her ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: My dear , she 's a perfect nonentity ; she might just as well not exist .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Amused .Well , to tell the truth , I do n't care much about her myself . She 's one of those boring creatures who when you ask her how she is , really tells you !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: You with fancy work ! What in the world are you doing ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I am knitting a tie for Dick !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Good gracious . Well , I 'll go upstairs and get into something loose . I 'll be ready in ten minutes .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I must see the children ; I have n't seen them to-day .

div.stage: She follows her mother out .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Miss Carley .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , Bella .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Mr. Coleman , Lieutenant Coleman , is going to the Philippines to-day .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sighing involuntarily .Yes , Bella .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I 've got a friend going along .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: In the company ?

lg.l: Yes — well , I do n't mind telling you — he 's my young man , Miss
Carley .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why , Bella , I did n't know you were engaged ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Well , I do n't know as you 'd call it exactly , yes I would say as we was engaged — though I have n't got a ring . But we 're going to get married when he comes back , if hugging and kissing is binding , which I guess , with witnesses ! He wanted to give me a ring of his mother 's , but I said “ No , ” I would n't take that , it was sacred and he 'd always wore it . You see it was an old-fashioned-looking sort of onyx stone with oyster pearls , and not for me — I 'd rather wait .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You have an eye out on the main chance , Bella .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Well , I was n't born yesterday . Say , all the girls was crazy about him . I met him to dancing school Tuesday evenings at Adelphi Hall and we started right in , every Sunday night to church and every Saturday to the theatre . He enjoyed Sundays best and I Saturdays , but I felt it was because church was cheapest . He 's dreadful economical .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You get more attention than I do from my soldier . You at least have the consolation of knowing you 're the girl he 's left behind .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: ‘ Tai n't much consolation if I get left for good ! Say , will you ask Mr. Coleman to sort o ’ look after him ? Ask him to please put him in the back row when there 's fighting — and keep an eye on his health . I 'm afraid it 's dreadful damp being a soldier ; and do you know that man actually catches cold if he forgets his rubbers and it sprinkles ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I do n't think he ought to go if he 's so delicate ; Mr. Coleman will take an interest in your friend , I know , if I ask him . What 's his name ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Mr. Gootch .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mr. Gootch ! Yes , I can remember that . But , you see , if he 's a soldier he must do his duty , whatever it is .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: There 's no holding him back ! He 's jus ’ as likely as not to lose his position at Snipleys , Crabford & Snipleys , too , but he will go ! It 's surprising to see a man with such a weak chest and delicate feet , so awful brave and persistent .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Coming back .I bore the children to death , so I left them . What are all these bundles , Bella ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Christmas presents . This is just the time of the year to buy , you know , you can get such bargains ! and if there 's one thing I think nicer'n anything else to get cheap , it 's Christmas presents .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You should do like Mrs. Carley , Bella , save half of the things you get one year to give away the next .

div.stage: She sits by the table and goes on with her work .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I always do that . I get so many things I can n't bear .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But you must be careful not to send them back to the same place they came from ! That has happened .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Georgiana !

div.stage: BELLA laughs out loud and sits on the sofa . LOUISE sits opposite GEORGIANA .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What have you got ? Sit down and tell us .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Thank you , ma'am .Delighted with the opportunity . Taking up the different parcels .Well , I 've got an elegant pair of scissors for mother , marked down because of a flaw in the steel , but she 's near-sighted , and she do n't want to use ‘ em anyway — it 's just to feel she has another pair . Scissors is mother 's fad — sort of born in her , I guess , for my mother 's mother was a kind of dressmaker . She did n't have robes and mantucks over her door , you know ,— she was too swell for that ,— she went out by the day ! And this is a real bronze Louis ink-stand for my sister 's husband , only cost thirty-nine cents and has n't got a thing the matter with it , so long as you do n't see the others — if you see the others , you 'll observe that there 's a naked lady missing off the top part which I 'm glad of anyway as I 'm giving it to a gentleman , and he 'll never see the others besides . And this is two boxes of writing paper ; are n't they huge ! awful cheap with a lovely picture of an actress on top — Lillian Russell in Mice and Men , I think , on one , and Jean Duresk the Opera Singer in Lonegrind on the other . The boxes ‘ av got false bottoms — so there ai n't very much writing material , but the rich effect 's there all the same .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughing .Bella , you 're a wonderful shopper !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: And this is a copy of Homer 's Iliad for my sister . Do you know it ? Is it nice ? Anything like Hall Caine 's works , or Mary Corelli 's ? She 's always been my sister 's favorite writeress . You see they 've got a whole counter of these beautifully bound in red and gold , and only nineteen cents . But it 's so hard to decide which to buy . I 've about decided now to take this back and change it for Lucille . Which do you think my sister 'd like best , Homer 's Iliad or Lucille ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I believe she 'd prefer Lucille , and besides half the fun in shopping is in the changing one 's mind and taking things back , do n't you think so ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Yes , ma'am , I think so .

div.stage: MOLES enters Left .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Mr. Coast to see Miss Georgiana , please .

div.stage: BELLA rises .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Did you say I was in ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , miss .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What a bore ! Very well , Moles .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I 'll be going up to Mrs. Carley , now .

div.stage: Goes toward the door Right .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Wait a minute , Bella . I want you to do something for me . Entertain Sammy , Louise , till I come back .

div.stage: She goes out with BELLA .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I never was able to entertain Sammy , but I 'll do my best .

div.stage: COAST enters , announced by MOLES , who immediately exits .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Hello , Lou , how goes it ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Beastly !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Where 's Miss Georgiana ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: She 'll be down in a minute . Sam , do you know what 's the matter with Steve ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Probably he 's been losing .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Whose money ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Everybody 's .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: But can n't you help him ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No ; it 's not my business .

div.stage: Sits on the sofa , putting the pillows out of his way .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: But he 's my husband , and you 're my cousin .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What 's the difference ? Twenty years ago , when your father was rich as Croesus and my guv'ner and I up a stump for — tobacco , anyway , if not for bread , did he lift a finger to help us ? not on your life ! That lets me out ! Every man for himself — and listen , if I wanted to starve I could lose a real good fortune through Steve Carley , without any outside help .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I told mother you 'd be like that .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: We 're all pretty much alike ; she 'd recognize the Coast family .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: If you were married to Georgiana , you could n't ignore her brother . She is n't like us .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , if I could get Georgiana ,Going to LOUISE .I 'd be willing to do a good deal . She 's the only woman I can see in this world my size .

lg.l: So I guessed , but if Dick Coleman proposes before he goes to the
Philippines , I would n't give much for your chances .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen , Lou ; did you ever know me to lose anything I 'd set my mind on getting .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well I mean to marry Georgiana , Dick Coleman or no Dick Coleman . No , I 'll put it different from that . I mean to make her love me , because , by God , I love that woman so I 'd do anything , commit a crime almost , to get her .

div.stage: STEVEN enters Left and COAST goes up to the mantel .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Steve , are n't you up town early ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: A little .

div.stage: Sits Left . MOLES enters .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Beg pardon , sir .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: What is it , Moles ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: To LOUISE .Mr. Carley , m 'm .To STEVEN .Could I speak with you a few moments , sir ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'm very busy to-day , Moles .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: But have you noticed sir , this morning , United Copper is lower .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: It can n't be helped — go about your business .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: But for heaven 's sake , Mr. Carley — you said yesterday if it dropped another point and we could n't give up any more money , Lizzie and me 'd both lose everything we had .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'm sorrier than I can say , but there are lots of others worse off than you .

div.stage: GEORGIANA reënters Right .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Cynically to STEVEN .You do n't mean to say you 've been speculating with Moles 's money .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Moles !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: It was for himself , not me , I put him in .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: And Lizzie , sir . And we 'd counted it up , how if we made all you said , we could leave service soon , sir , and we could afford a small house in the country with say four rooms and one baby — Lizzie doing her own work .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Do you mean to say , Steve , that your own servants have lost their earnings through you ?

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , m 'm .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Doggedly .Put it that way if you like . I meant to do them a good turn .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: But we can n't let that happen ; we must pay them back !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Amused .Bully for you , Louise ! getting generous in your old age .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: It would ruin us socially if it got out !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , I see !

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Mr. Carley said it was sure , ma'am .

div.stage: COAST laughs a rather coarse laugh .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: For heaven 's sake , Coast ! Go away , Moles .

div.stage: MOLES goes out Left .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: To STEVEN .Are they holding on for you ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: They said they 'd give me till to-morrow to put up more security .

div.stage: Sits Right .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What do you need ?

div.stage: No answer .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: How much more security , Steve ?

div.stage: Goes to STEVE .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Say a hundred and fifty thousand .
