div.stage: COAST whistles .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: He 'd better hold on , Sam , had n't he ; what do you think of the stock ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do n't ask me .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: We 've got to risk it , anyway . Use some of my bonds , Steve .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Louise !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes , I mean it , we must .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: You do n't understand me — we can n't use your security .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Rising and half turning away .Not — again .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: How do you mean “ again ” ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Your money is all there , all , already buried in it !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: All my money ? All of it !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , I wanted to win back your mother 's , I wanted —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Beside herself .You wanted ! You wanted !! You wanted !!! To ruin us , that is what I should say you wanted to do !— Do you mean to say , behind my back , you 've gambled away every cent I have , as well as all my mother 's money !? !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ! it 's not possible — Steve !

div.stage: Comes between STEVEN and LOUISE .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: When did you come in , Georgy ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Georgy !No answer ; she continues hysterically .He can n't deny it ; it 's true ! And it 's rank dishonesty , that 's what it is ! You 've robbed me , you 've robbed my mother , you 've robbed your own children ! The papers will call you a —

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Interrupting .That 's not true ! I had control of your money — to do with as I choose , and I did what I thought was for the best .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: You 've never done anything for me that was n't for the worst !

div.stage: Walking up and down excitedly .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Louise !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: It 's true ! If I can save a cent out of this ruin , I 'll take it and the children away from you ! I 'll never live with you again ! I 'll show you up to all your smart friends who 've snubbed me ! I 'll send you to state prison if I can !

div.stage: Sits in the arm-chair down Left .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Shut up , Lou ! You 'd better get a little legal advice before you start on that track .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Louise !

div.stage: Goes to LOUISE .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Well , what have you got to say ? My mother brought you up , was a second mother to your brother who ruined us , but you 've got your money , I suppose . You 've been clever enough to keep your money in your own hands ,— you and he will always have enough !

div.stage: Crying hysterically .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Will you listen to me and let me say what I 'm trying to ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Bursting into floods of tears , overwhelmed with sympathy for herself .He 's broken my heart ! That 's what he 's done ; broken my heart !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Going to LOUISE .Oh , no , he has n't , Louise , he 's only broken your bank , and you do n't know the difference . I want to say to you now ,— that all Steve needed was real love , and the guiding hand of a true , sensible woman —

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Interrupting her , goes to GEORGIANA . GEORGIANA turns to STEVE .No , Georgy ! You must n't blame Louise ! I love her and always will , just as she is . She does n't mean all she says now — she 's angry , and she has a right to be — I 'm one of those men who never succeed — who never have any luck , and it 's bad luck for her to have to share mine .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , what 's done 's done ? But , as Louise says , my money 's left .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , but —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mine must do for all of us .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Strongly .Excuse me , but I 'll see that Louise and her mother do n't suffer ; you keep your money .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , that 's not the point , Sam . I asked you once to give my brother advice and you refused . You might have prevented this , and now we can get along without your money . Steve wo n't have to go out of his own family to make up as far as he can for what he 's lost out of yours .

div.stage: SAM turns away to the mantel .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Georgy ! O Georgy ! You 're an angel !Hugging her and kissing her in a transport of relief .I 'll get out of it , you 'll see ! I 'll cover myself to-morrow . I can do that with your Croton Bonds and your Mutual Life and a couple of mortgages , and we 'll win in the end , and Louise get hers back and mother too —!His arm about his wife .It 's sure in the end , it 's got to be , Louise .

div.stage: There is no response from LOUISE .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Steven , I have a condition about my money .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Crestfallen .What ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: It is n't to be used as you think . If I 'm to help you , it must be in my own way .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: How do you mean ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What 's lost is lost . I have between five and six hundred thousand dollars , and we must all live on the income of that . And you must give your word of honor never to gamble in stocks again .

div.stage: SAM comes back to front of table .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: To STEVEN , suddenly realizing it again .You let all my money go ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: To LOUISE .I will share what I have with you .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: To GEORGIANA .But you must let me try to get back —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Interrupting .It would only be throwing good money after bad !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Sardonically .How about Moles and Lizzie ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't you worry about them ! Moles and Lizzie shall have their money back , of course .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But I can n't do it , Georgy . It 's losing — why it 's like losing a million to us !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Suppose you went on speculating with my money , and it went the same way as Louise 's and her mother 's ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And Lizzie 's and Moles ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But it can n't — it can n't !

div.stage: STEVEN sits on the sofa . GEORGIANA sits beside STEVEN . LOUISE is still in the arm-chair Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: O Steve ! I 've heard that so often .A pause .You were always a straight boy , Steve , and you always kept your word . Your notion of honor , it seems to me , in little things has n't been so strong lately , as this fever of speculation grew on you , but still you are the same Steve and you 've never lied about your transactions ; so I have faith in you . Now let 's settle this once and for all and my way !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: It 's very hard , Georgiana .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: We can never all of us live on your income — not as we 're used to .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's true . Come , Steve . Give me your word never to go into another speculation and let 's throw it off for to-day . Dick 's coming to say good-by . Let 's give him happy memories of us , at least to take away with him .A moment 's pause .Come , Steve ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Low voice .All right .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No more speculating ; you 'll give me your word —STEVEN rises , GEORGIANA rises . STEVEN nods his head .— of honor , Steve ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes !

div.stage: Nods his head .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Then that 's settled .

div.stage: Gives SAM a calm , defiant look .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: O Georgy ! I do n't seem grateful , but I am . I can n't tell you ! I can n't say ! But it 's wonderful what you 're doing ! God bless you !

div.stage: Puts his arms on GEORGIANA 'S shoulders .

lg.l: That 's all right ,
Steve . We 'll begin all over again .

div.stage: She kisses him .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: To GEORGIANA .I suppose I ought to thank you too .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , do n't bother . Come upstairs and have your hair shampooed . Bella must have painted mother red enough by now ; it 'll rest you and do you good .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: After all , you 're no real relation of ours , and you 've done a fine thing .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Very simply .Do n't talk about it . I wish it were more . I realize fully what it means to your mother and you to have all your money gone . But we 'll put our shoulders to the wheel and make the best of it . Come , dear , come .

div.stage: She goes out Right . LOUISE is about to follow , but is stopped by STEVEN .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Louise , do you forgive me ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No , you ought to have asked my advice — let me know .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But when I used to talk to you about money matters , dear , you always begged me not to bother you .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I do n't care , this is different . Sam !

div.stage: Nodding good-by .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do you mind my joining you to see the procession go by at five ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No !

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: What procession ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Coleman 's regiment .

div.stage: He puts his feet upon small gilt chair beside the table .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , yes ! Well — I 've made a pretty big mess of things . I 'm not fit to live , that 's what 's the trouble with me .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , you must take everything in the day 's work ; but it 's a pity she made you give her that promise .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Goes to him .You all can n't live on the income from five hundred thousand dollars . Now there 'll be a bust up sure !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Ss ! that 's all I need .

div.stage: Sits on the sofa .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That promise of yours to Georgiana 's binding , ai n't it ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Looks up .Of course . Why ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No why .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: You think United Copper will go up again ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: If not , I know something that will .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Something you 're in yourself ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: And you 'd put me on ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yep . I do n't think there 's any other way out of this for you all .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Sam !

div.stage: He rises .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: It 's absolutely safe .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I could get it back ? Some , anyway , of what I 've lost ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Sure !—

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But I gave Georgiana my word .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Of course she got that promise out of you because she thought you 'd lose again .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , but my word is my word .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do you suppose she 'd mind , if you won , won back Louise 's money , won back the girl 's happiness ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Suppose I tell her what you can do and ask her to let me off this once ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No , women do n't understand business . She would n't realize I can know I 'd win , any more than you feel sure and lose .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , it would do no good to ask her .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Too bad , because I 'd guarantee you would n't lose , not this deal . Of course I would n't be responsible for any future transaction .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But I 'd be satisfied with this one , if I got back my losses .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I do n't say you 'd get back all , in one deal , but a good start which might turn your luck .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: It 's always like that ; I 've known such cases over and over again . But I 've never yet broken my word to Georgiana ,— somehow or other I feel as if I did that once I would n't have any hold over myself .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I do n't suppose you could get at her securities anyway this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , yes , I could . We have our deposit box together .

lg.l: Do n't you think she 'd forgive you when it means such a lot to
Louise and her mother ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Why should n't she ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why do n't you risk it ? That promise was just to keep you from losing , and this time I 'll see you do n't lose — so why not ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: By George , I will ! Georgiana really can n't blame me when there 's so much at stake .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Can you get the stuff to-day ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Looks at his watch .Yes , if I hurry .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: All right , go ahead . I 'll come to your office to-morrow at nine . Listen — I ai n't supposed , of course , to have anything to do with this — and when you get it , do n't go giving my tip to other chumps .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , no .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What you do is on your own responsibility ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Exactly , only you guarantee ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That you do n't lose this time .Looking at his watch .You 'd better hurry .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Thank you , Sam .

div.stage: Shakes his hand .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right . Say , I want to marry your sister . No objection on your part , is there ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Well , I should say not !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: She do n't seem to cotton to me .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: She does n't know you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do you think if she was up a tree for funds she 'd look at me any kinder ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Not a bit .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Some women do .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Not Georgiana ! Good-by .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: To STEVE .So long .

div.stage: STEVEN turns to go , but stops as MOLES shows COLEMAN into the room . The latter is dressed in his uniform of first lieutenant .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Hello , Steven ! Hello , Coast !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: We gates !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: How are you , Dick ? Excuse me , I 'm in a hurry . You 're off to-day ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes , I 've come to shake hands .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Good-by , old man , and good luck — sorry to have to go ! Good-by !

div.stage: Shakes hands warmly , with feeling .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Good-by .

div.stage: STEVEN goes out Left .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Sitting Right .Oh , I guess she ai n't so different .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Georgiana , she 's just a woman !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No , take my word for it , she 's not a woman , she 's the woman .

div.stage: Sits on the piano bench .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: ‘ Spose she likes money and nice things always about her ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: She 's always had them ,— and always would if I could help give them to her .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Huh , huh ! Well — say , Steve 's got himself in a devil of a hole ! Speculated with his wife 's money — and they 're broke .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Good God , what do you mean ?

div.stage: Rises .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What I say . Steve is one of those good-hearted gulls who 's a blame slob on the money market , and he 's gone under to the extent of Aunt Laura 's and Louise 's spondulix , that 's all .

div.stage: He is rather amused . DICK goes back of table , puts his hat on it .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: What are they going to do ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Georgiana wants to pony up like a brick and keep the whole lot !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Just like her !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , of course , I 'll see Georgiana do n't really lose by it in no way in the end .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: You will ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why of course !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: She is n't going to let Steve speculate with her money , is she ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Ca n't say .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Look here , I 'd like to help Steve myself , if I thought I could protect Georgiana . I 'll let Steve have some money . You need n't say anything to anybody . How much will see him through ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That 's real good of you , but I could n't let outsiders help ‘ em .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I 'm not exactly an outsider ; and the truth is , Coast , I 'd give anything to have the right to help Georgiana .A silence .Look here . I 'm going to ask you a question , straight out !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Fire ahead !

div.stage: Looks at DICK with a perfectly blank face .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Anything between you and Georgiana ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: After a short pause .There is —

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Mrs. Carley hinted as much .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Unflinchingly .I 'm — er — I 'm going to marry Georgiana .

div.stage: A pause . COAST looks DICK in the eye , then away .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Congratulate you , Coast !Shakes his hand .She 's worth even more than you can give her !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That 's right !

div.stage: COAST goes out on the balcony and whistles “ Congo . ” DICK walks away and turns his back . DICK goes to the mantel and takes up a picture of GEORGIANA , looks at it , takes it out of the frame , and seeing that COAST is n't observing , puts it in his breast pocket . He turns round with a pathetic sort of half-laughing exclamation to COAST .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I say , Coast .COAST comes in from the balcony .I 've been in love with Georgiana for years .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That do n't surprise me !

div.stage: COAST sits on the piano bench .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I never realized it until the other day , when I found I was going to leave her , and — perhaps — not coming back , and then I found boy friendship had sort of grown up into a man 's love — I almost told her —Pause .I wonder if I 'd found it out sooner — before you came along —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No use shutting the stable door after the horse is swiped !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I sha n't be able to say exactly what I wanted to to Georgiana — but that 's — your luck — I guess the quicker I can say good-by and get out , the better for me —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen — do n't say anything to Georgiana about her and me , will you , unless of course she tells you — we 're not talking about it yet .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I do n't care mentioning it , thank you .

div.stage: MRS. CARLEY and GEORGIANA come in Right and meet DICK .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: We 're so sorry to say good-by , Dick — will you have some tea ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No , thanks .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Hello , Auntie .

div.stage: MRS. CARLEY goes to the sofa and sits with her crocheting .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Dick !

div.stage: Shaking his hand — a second long . They look into each other 's eyes .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Is n't he fine in his uniform ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Embarrassed .I had n't time to change before we start .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Louise asks me to give her farewells ; she 's got a bad headache and is being shampooed — she 's too disappointed not to see you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I 'm sorry she 's in her usual health .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Got it from her father ; we did n't expect him to live a year when I married him , but he surprised us all — and I tell Louise she 'll outlive me yet . How are you , Sammy ?

div.stage: Drops her worsted ; COAST picks it up and gives it to her .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: All right , only I need a shave .

div.stage: He sits Left .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Well , you should n't talk about it ! You need a lot of coaching .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Aside to DICK .Stay ; I want to speak to you alone .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: All right , old girl , I think I know why .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Why do n't you all sit down ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: He has n't much time .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I have n't long to stay . I must be at the armory by a quarter to four .

lg.l: You march by here at four , do n't you , on your way to the 42d
St. Station ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes , rather a bore ; but the Governor insists , and Roosevelt comes on to receive us at 59th St .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: We ought n't to keep Dick , then , mother ; we ought to say good-by at once .

div.stage: They all rise .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Very well , speed the parting guest ! Good-by , Dick , we 'll watch the papers to see what brave things you do , and do n't fall in love with any of the décolleté young nigger ladies we read about .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Good-by , Mrs. Carley .They wait for GEORGIANA to say good-by . A pause .Good-by , Coast !

div.stage: Crosses to COAST , who rises and shakes hands with DICK .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Good-by ! Good luck —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Pointedly .Good-by , Sam .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , I 'm not going .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: To GEORGIANA .Good-by .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good-by !Shakes his hand and adds under her breath to him .Do n't go . Do n't go .

div.stage: A pause ; all wait .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: He is n't in a hurry , after all , Georgiana ; let 's all sit down again .

div.stage: They all sit .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughing , embarrassed .Of course I do n't want to urge you off , Dick .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Rising .No , but really , after all , I think I must go .

div.stage: All rise again .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ! Mother , I want to speak with Dick alone , before he goes ; you wo n't mind leaving us , will you , you and Sam ?

div.stage: Sam rises .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Unwilling .Oh , no — Come along , Sam . We 'll be on the balcony when you pass , Dick ; be sure to look up . Good-by .

div.stage: Going .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Shaking her hand .I 'll look up .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: At the door Right .I 'll go up and see the kids .

div.stage: COAST looks at Dick and goes out very slowly with MRS. CARLEY .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I could n't say good-by to you like that — I could n't share my good-by with mother ; you understand that , do n't you , Dick .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes , old girl , though if I had my way I would n't say good-by to you at all — I hate good-bys to people I care about .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sit down just a few minutes .

div.stage: They sit down by the table .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Sees the tie in her hands .Busy making reins for Toots ? What an ugly color !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Is it ? Well , it 's a tie for you !

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Oh — I mean it 's ugly for reins , but perfectly lovely for a tie — I 'll take it with me .

div.stage: Puts it in his pocket .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I wish I could go with you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Do n't you think you 're needed here just at this moment ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Has Steve told you ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No , Coast did .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't you think I 'm doing right ?

lg.l: If you love him , of course , old girl , you 're doing right . I think
I must go now .
Good-by .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , do n't go yet , please . I can n't bear to have you go .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 's good of you to care so much .Leans against the table .You know only yesterday I woke up and suddenly began to hope —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What —

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Nothing ; I do n't hope it any more , anyway ! I say , Georgiana , you 'll go around and see mother and father once in a while , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Of course I will —

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: It 'll cheer them up a lot , you know — they feel so badly ; it 's pretty tough on them , my leaving .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I feel badly too —

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: That 's jolly good of you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And is n't it just a little tough to leave me ? Your oldest friend almost , you know .

div.stage: She adds this latter to cover up the sentiment which was coming too near the surface .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Of course it is .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You have n't said so .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Still waters run deep , Georgy , and I —He moves away .really , I must be going .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Rising .No , do n't go .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Looking at his watch .I must .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , let me see your watch . Yes , you have got three more minutes . Please — sit down —

div.stage: She persuades him to sit down again , and she reseats herself .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Have your own way !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Will there be fighting ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I hope so !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , but what fighting ! I 've read , I know — ambushes and tortures — their war is murder .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes , and that 's why we 're going out there to put an end to it .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why need you ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Some one must , I as well as another ; in fact , just now , I better than any other .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why you better ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Because I want to go — I 've got a restless fit , Georgiana — and want to get away from here — I want to get away from everybody .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: From me ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Yes , even from you !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Hurt .Thank you .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I should think your woman 's instinct would teach you why .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , it does n't ! and I really should be very much obliged to you if you would help my woman 's instinct out .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Of course it 's all right what you 're going to do , only — well , I do n't want to be here to see it .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But , Dick , I 'm perfectly happy in what I 'm doing .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Of course ! but that does n't make it any the pleasanter for me .Rises .Good-by .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Rising .And that 's all , just good-by ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: No , I wish you all kinds of happiness in the future and the happiest marriage in the world .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , thank you very much .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: With great effort .I wish you everything that 's good , Georgy , old girl !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , I 'm sure no one could ask for more ; and what shall I wish you ?

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Wish me a big fight , and an exciting one ! Wish me a chance to do something ! Wish me — oh , what does it matter — wish me — “ Good-by . ”

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What does it matter ? Good-by ! No !

div.stage: They shake hands ; she follows him to the door .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: I must . I 'll be late .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Be late .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Looking at her a moment .I am — too late . Good-by .

div.stage: He is going out again and she stops him . Good-by . [ Light-heartedly .
He goes out . She stands where he leaves her , facing the door . A pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: “ What does it matter ” — “ wish me good-by . ”

div.stage: She turns , looking straight ahead of her , gazing into space , realizing what it means to her . Slowly the emotion creeps into her face , she falters where she stands , and turns about to burst into tears , when COAST comes back into the room .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I heard Coleman go — can I talk with you a little ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sitting on the sofa .No , Sam , I do n't feel like it !

div.stage: She cannot keep her tears back .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Going to her .Georgy , do n't — do n't — I love you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ! I do n't want you to .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: It do n't make any difference if you want me to or not ; I do , got to , it 's so strong in me — wo n't you have me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ! Wo n't you leave me alone a little ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No , I can n't . Listen ; I know I 'm not refined enough for you — but I can get over that in time . Sure ! I can get over everything for you , if you 'll only love me .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ! now go away from me .

div.stage: He kneels beside her a little awkwardly , trying to make her look at him .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: There is n't a thing in this world that money can buy I wo n't give you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: There are some things money can n't buy .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No , there ai n't — not my money ! You 'll have everything a woman can hanker after in this world — the best there is , and Steve shall have it , too , for your sake .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I can never love you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen ! I 'll make my wife the biggest woman in the city — I 'll make her —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Interrupting .Sam , stop !He rises .I can n't hear any more !

div.stage: A pause — she sobs ; he waits .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I wo n't stop , not till you say you 'll marry me ! If I let up to-day , I 'll begin again to-morrow , and when I stop to-morrow it 'll be to go ahead the day after ! I 've never failed yet in getting anything I 've set after , and this is the biggest thing I 've ever made up my mind to .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And this time you will lose . Because I can never love you .He tries to interrupt .No , let me finish . I 'll tell you why I can n't love you . I 'll tell you , only just you , Sam , remember that . I could never love you because I love now , with every bit of love there is in me , the man who has just left this house , who has gone to fight and perhaps will never come back .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Has he asked you to be his wife ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I love him all the same !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And I love you the same way you love him — ai n't you a little sorry for me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That 'll do to go on with —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Laughs hysterically .Oh — Sam , can n't I make you understand ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No , nor make me give up . I 'm coming to see you again to-morrow ; when will you be in ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Not at all .

div.stage: She moves about the room .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What time in the afternoon ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I shall be out all afternoon .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'll call at five .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Very well ! You 'll find Louise and mother .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Coleman thinks you 'll have me !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: He could n't ! Why should he ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: He congratulated me , when he was here just now !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: For what ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: For you !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh !Laughing hysterically .That 's what he meant by his happy marriage —

div.stage: Laughing and crying .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: If he mentioned marriage , that 's what he meant .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But did n't you tell him he was wrong ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But why not ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I wanted him to think it !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But it was wrong of you — it can never be true , and I do n't want him to go away believing it .Music of a military band is heard in the distance .Here they come !Going to the balcony , he follows .No , please do n't come out with me ! Sam — I do n't want him to see me standing there with you .SAM starts towards GEORGIANA .Let me go out on the balcony alone , Sam ! Please , alone !

div.stage: He looks at her a moment and then deliberately goes past her out on to the balcony .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Hurrying in from the Right .They 're coming ! I 've told the children .

div.stage: She goes out on balcony . The children run in .

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHILDREN
sp.p: The soldiers are coming ! Auntie , the soldiers are coming !

div.stage: They rush out on the balcony .

lg.stage: In the window , picking up PHIL in his arms .
lg.l: Come on ,
Georgy . What does it matter ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's true , go on ! What does it matter , it 's good-by !COAST goes on the balcony . MRS. CARLEY , on balcony , calls , “ Here comes DICK ! ” GEORGIANA hesitates and then goes close to the window . She stands in a chair so as to see over the others ’ heads , hidden behind the curtain of the half-open window , and watches . The music is louder as they pass under the balcony ; a flag is seen almost on level with the balcony floor . Those on the balcony wave and shout , and shouts are heard in the street . GEORGIANA stands still , wiping the tears from her eyes every moment with a tiny wad of a handkerchief , and as the music passes , growing less loud ,THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: Eight months later . GEORGIANA 'S room , an octagonal room with dark panel walnut woodwork and panels of yellow brocade , with furniture to match . All in the simplest style of Louis XV . There is a fireplace on the Left , and doors Right and Left . Two windows at the back . At right of the Centre is a very large dressing table covered with massive silver toilet articles , a big mirror , candelabra , etc ., and a silver-framed , photograph of DICK COLEMAN . There is a low bench before the table , tables and chairs about the room , and a most comfortable , roomy sofa , on the Left , piled with embroidered pillows . It is after seven and the lamps are lit . STEVEN enters from Left and sits on the sofa . He is haggard , his clothes mussed , his linen rumpled and soiled . He is painfully nervous and agitated ; he cannot keep still ; as soon as he sits down he gets up ; he goes from one place in the room to another , taking up a picture without looking at it , sitting down and getting up again . Twice he half whispers , half groans , “ Good God ! ” He takes out a pistol from his pocket , looks at it , and puts it away again as LIZZIE enters Right .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Miss Carley says she 'll be in as soon as she can .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Rising and going to the dressing table .Is she dressing for the ball now ?

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: No , sir , she 's wearing a tea gown for dinner ; it 'll be a grand sight , the ball , sir !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I suppose so .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Pity we could n't ‘ ave got the Grand Duke here , sir , to dinner .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Moving about .We could n't afford to entertain a Russian prince , Lizzie ,— do n't tell your mistress ,— but I 've been speculating again and we 're hard up .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Oh , I am so sorry , sir — I know how to sympathize with you , though we did get our money back ! Perhaps you 'll get yours .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: How about you and Moles ?

div.stage: Comes to LIZZIE .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: Well , sir , last Tuesday we counted up , we 're about two years off , or fourteen hundred dollars distance , so to speak . We 've calculated then we could marry and settle down if we 'd be satisfied with two rooms and no children .

div.stage: There is a knock on door Left . Yes ? [ Going to the door , opens it . ] Oh , come in , sir . [ Moves away . ] Mr. Carley is here .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Entering .Where 's Miss Georgiana ?

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: She 's dressing , sir . She 'll be down in five or ten minutes .

div.stage: Goes out Right .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: How are you ?

div.stage: The two men nod a surly greeting .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 've been looking for you all afternoon !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Did n't you know I was coming here and going with your folks to the ball ?

lg.l: I forgot !
lg.stage: After a pause , both men look at each other .
lg.l: Well , Sam , I 'm done ! I 'm done for good this time !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Sorry , but you can n't blame me .

div.stage: He sits in an arm-chair near the sofa .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I do . You told me you were going into this last business , but you did n't tell me you were going to get right out again .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: ‘ Twas n't my business to tell you that — I did n't advise you to go in !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: No , but you put me up to it all the same !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Not a bit ! The only time I advised you was some months ago , when you 'd just lost Louise 's money ,— then I put you on to something , so you should n't lose Georgiana 's . Did you win ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , and broke my word to Georgiana .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , that 's her and your business , but it let me out ! From that time on you were on your own hook .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: You were always throwing out hints that you meant me to take .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen .Rises and goes to STEVEN .You can n't prove that !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: You know you led me into it , you know you did . You tempted me in the first place to break my word of honor to my sister . Whether you meant to or not , you did it , damn you — and you 're a rich man , you 've got millions , and can help me out ! Will you ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Quietly .No .

div.stage: Moves a little away toward the Left .

sp.speaker: STEVE
sp.p: You 're my wife 's own cousin , and she 's a pauper and through no fault of her own . Will you help me for her sake ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Still quietly .No .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: You 're in love with my sister , and she 's not got a cent of her own to-night through me . Will you help me for her sake ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Still quietly .No !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Going to him .No ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No !

div.stage: Strong .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Then damn you for a dirty blackguard !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Laughs .That 's pretty talk ; I guess you got that from me too !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Doggedly .I 'll do more than talk !

div.stage: Turns away and goes up stage .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Wait and see .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Listen ! if one thing happens , I 'll help you .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Turning .You mean Georgiana !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes , if she 'll marry me , I 'll make up to you every damn cent of hers you 've got rid of .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: And if she wo n't ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'll make up every penny of Louise 's you 've lost , if Georgiana 'll marry me . Listen —SAM puts his arm around STEVEN and brings him down to the sofa and they sit .she loves you , you 're the kind that always has influence with women ; use yours for me , Steve , it 'll be worth your while .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Half laughs .You want me to try and persuade her to marry you against her own desire even ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That 's the figure .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: When I know you 're , in your way , just as dishonorable a man as I am , and hard and heartless ,STEVE rises .I would n't risk my sister 's happiness with you , if it would save me twice over . Even if she loved you , I 'd say what I could against it .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Quick .She 'll never know you broke your word to her if I help you .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , she will , because I mean to tell her to-night .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: All right !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: That 's what I 've come for , to make a clean breast of everything .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: You 're a damned fool !He rises and moves away .However , each way plays more or less into my hands .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Outside of door Right .If you are telling secrets , look out — I 'm coming !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Come on !

div.stage: GEORGIANA comes in , dressed in graceful negligée tea gown .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good evening , Sam ! Steve , you 're not dressed yet ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I forgot about the ball .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I can tell you one person who has n't , and that 's mother !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Laughing .Is she going to be corking ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sitting in the arm-chair by the sofa .If the Grand Duke were a bachelor and mother had designs upon him , she could n't possibly take more pains ! She 's going to be beyond all words . She 's got every jewel she owns and can borrow draped about her , till she looks like Tiffany 's exhibit at the St. Louis Fair . And as for her hair , she 's had Bella Shindle working on it all afternoon , till it 's the Titianest Titian that ever flamed on human head !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Sounds great !

div.stage: Sitting on the bench . STEVEN sits on the sofa .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Wait ! She 's built her tiara up with a breastpin and an aigrette off my winter hat , and it was all I could do to keep her from wearing the three feathers in which she was presented to the Queen in A. D. ‘ 73 .

div.stage: They all laugh good-naturedly .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Aunt Laura 's a corker !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , no one will miss her ! She 'll get the Grand Duke 's eye if no one else does ! I tell her she 'll go through the ballroom like a search-light !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Is she all dressed now ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Not yet . I 'm judging by her dress rehearsal ! I left her in a state of terrible indecision as to whether she should arch her eyebrows “ just a little ” with a burnt match !

div.stage: All laugh again good-naturedly .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Smart old girl !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: She 's all the happier for being silly , and she 's a good soul and does her best ! What 's your news , Steve ?

div.stage: Turning to STEVEN .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Sam , would you mind ?

div.stage: Motions to COAST to leave the room .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , no !Rises .See you later ! I 'll go and take a squint at auntie .

div.stage: He goes out Right .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Steve , you look troubled — what 's gone wrong ?

div.stage: She goes to STEVEN on the sofa and sits beside him .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I have !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: How do you mean ? You and Louise have n't quarrelled ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: If it was only that !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What then ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 've gone wrong , I tell you , all wrong .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: How ? In what way , Steve ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Your money 's lost , it 's all lost .

div.stage: GEORGIANA rises . A pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: How do you mean ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: And that is n't the worst of it , either . I 've broken my word to you ! I know I 've killed your faith in me . I 've lost faith in myself .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Still standing , very strong .Steve !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 've speculated !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , Steve !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Rises and goes to the mantel .Yes , I 've been speculating since the very day I said I would n't . I won a lot at first , and of course I thought I 'd get all back ; and then , of course , what I did get back was my old cursed luck !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , Steve ! And I believed in you so thoroughly , I never had a doubt !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I know it ! I know it ! I 'm rotten all through , Georgy .Bursting into tears .I 'm not worth being forgiven —He falls on his knees , in a paroxysm of sobs and tears .I 'm rotten ! Oh — I 'm rotten —

div.stage: He sobs uncontrollably .
GEORGIANA watches him a little while in silence . Then she goes to him and puts her hand on his shoulder .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Steve !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Sobbing .Yes !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I forgive you !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: No ! No !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And I 'll trust you again if I have a chance .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Looking up .Georgy , what do you mean ?

div.stage: Beginning to control his sobs .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I mean , though it 's been a pretty big blow , my faith in you is n't altogether gone yet .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , I can n't bear it ! I can n't bear it ! But you do n't mean it ! No , you can n't mean it ! How could you ? Forgive me ? Trust me again ? No , no ! You could n't — it 's all over ! I 've thrown away my own money first , then my wife 's and her mother 's — that ought to have been enough ,— but I had to go and break my word of honor to you , and lose every penny of yours ! There 's no excuse for me , nor reason to forgive .

lg.stage: After a moment , very quietly , with her eyes filling .
lg.l: There 's love , Steve !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Not for a man like me . I 'm not worth it .He rises .Not deserving it ! There 's only one thing for such as me , and that is to end it all with a bullet .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Now you 're talking wildly !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: In a lowered voice .No , Georgy , I mean it ! It 's better for all of you to have me out of the way ; I tried to do it to-day — only , I was afraid !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That would be worse than anything you have done yet . That I would never forgive — anything but that !

div.stage: She goes to him .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But the shame of my life now , the degradation , the rot of it !

div.stage: A moment 's pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: The idea comes to her .Steve , I told you I 'd trust you again if I had the chance ! Here is the first one , and I take it ! Promise me you 'll never again even think of taking your life .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: What 's the good of my promising ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: If you tell me , I 'll believe you .A short pause .STEVEN , not looking at her , puts his hand in the pocket where the pistol is , then takes his hand away , still not looking at her .Look me straight in the face , Steve , and say , “ I promise . ”

div.stage: He hesitates only a moment , and then does so .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I promise .

div.stage: He turns a little away from her , takes the pistol from his pocket , and gives it to her .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Bursting into tears .Oh , Steve !

div.stage: She turns away and puts the pistol on the table between the windows .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Forgive me , Georgy , forgive me ! This promise I 'll keep . Only forgive me for breaking your heart like this !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Entering Right .I 've been sent up to bring you down to dinner .

div.stage: He takes in the situation . A pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do you know what Steve has just told me ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Bitterly .Yes , he knows .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Just what ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Steve has gone on speculating , and my money 's followed the rest .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes , I knew that .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Could n't you have saved him ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I offered to once , but you refused .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And now ?

div.stage: Short pause .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: He goes to GEORGIANA , who is on the sofa .My offer is still open to the same tune .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: No , Georgy , no !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: For Steve 's own sake , wo n't you do something for him ? Get him some position so that he can take care of Louise . I 'll look after myself .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'll do all and more , if you 'll marry me .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You know I can n't marry you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What does Steve say ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: What Georgy says , I say .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: How are you going to get out of this without me ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: And there 's something else .Steps towards STEVEN .Perhaps you do n't know that unless some one does get you out of this , it wo n't be only a money smash-up for Georgiana , but disgrace too !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That can n't be true ! I shall say my brother had control of my money to do what he liked with it .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: But any lawyer would take up the case of criminal mismanagement for my aunt and cousin 's affairs .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But they would n't allow it .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , what do you think ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Louise — never !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Leave it to me !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Ah ! your true colors ! You heard him , Georgy ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , let that pass . But you know that you 've overdrawn at your bank , that you 've overdrawn at your brokers , and that you can no more get out of the muddle you 've got yourself into without one of the biggest public scandals there 's been in the street for years !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But you can spare us that ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Very low .Good God !

div.stage: He moves away .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: To GEORGIANA .That 's what I can .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And you love me ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I certainly do !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Then you will spare us !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: If you 'll marry me .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: No !Comes down to her .Georgy , you must n't !COAST walks away .Do n't you see what a selfish brute Sam is ? Of course it was my fault that I gambled , but he tempted me , he led me into it when he knew I could n't resist . The very day and hour I gave you my promise , he gave me a tip and guaranteed I should n't lose !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sam ! Oh !

div.stage: She turns to the bench before her dressing table and sinks upon it .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Speaks to her across the table .It 's true ! And I led him to speculate more , I tricked him first with winning and then let him go ! I knew he 'd soon do for himself alone , and he did ! Yes — I ruined him purposely and you through him , so as to get you to be my wife . I did it purposely and I 'd do it again ! Of course I meant all along to make it up in the end when I 'd got you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And did you really think you could get me that way ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why , you 've got to marry me . You need n't be afraid of what I wo n't do for you . I love you , you know that . Everything — I 've told you that before . You shall have everything on God 's earth you want , and Louise and her mother shall live in style as they always have , and Steve have his own money back , with a brother-in-law to help him take care of it ! And what 's the other side of the picture ? Nothing for you or Louise or anybody — and disgrace for Steve into the bargain . Why , you 've got to marry me !GEORGIANA rises , COAST follows her .Do n't you see ? AnywaySmiling .it was only a trick to make you , because , Georgy , I love you so !A pause ; she stands looking at him .Well ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I 'm trying to realize — to understand it all .

div.stage: MOLES enters Left .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Please , miss , Mrs. Carley says your soup is all cold and they 're on with the fish .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Tell Mrs. Carley not to wait for Mr. Carley and me , we 're not coming down ; but Mr. Coast will join them in a moment .

div.stage: COAST looks up surprised .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , miss .

div.stage: He goes out . A moment 's pause .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: What do you mean by that ?

div.stage: Another pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Slowly .Not to save myself , not even to save my brother , and from even worse than we have to face , would I marry you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do n't say that , Georgy !

sp.speaker: GEORGY
sp.p: Why , every word you 've said , and everything you 've done to make me love you , makes me instead — yes — and for what you 've done with SteveLooks at STEVE ., I do hate you .

div.stage: Goes to the sofa , COAST follows .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I only said it because I love you , Georgiana .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , Sam Coast , you do n't know what love is ! Love does n't make beasts of men , it makes men of beasts . It does n't take all for itself — it sacrifices all for another . Love is n't an enemy that lays traps and makes ambushes ,— love is a friend whose heart is a divine magnet ! Real love makes an angel of a woman and a hero of a man , but love such as you have — oh , the happiness in this world that 's been lost through it !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: You do n't know me !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I did n't , but I do ! You 've dragged down my brother , sacrificed him and my belief in him , almost , for your own selfish end , tried to trap me into marrying you when you know I did n't love you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: But you would —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Once perhaps , though I can n't imagine it ! But not now ! No ! I 'd starve and suffer and die now before I could ever love you .

div.stage: A pause ; COAST goes to the table and stands half shamefaced a moment , then he pulls himself up and turns .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , face the music for a while , and then see !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: They 're waiting for you at dinner ; please join them and tell them what you like .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'll tell them nothing . I 'll let you and Steve think things over a little .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Rises , and goes to meet COAST .You will have something to settle with me outside of money matters !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: With a jeer .Please yourself .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: To STEVEN .I believe I can influence Louise to do nothing for the sake of the children , and she loves you in her way .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But the bank ?

div.stage: He sits on sofa beside her .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , we can take care of the bank ; after all , we 've friends , we 've jewels , we 've this house .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: That 's true , and the brokers ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Who are they ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Caldwell and Hovery .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mr. Caldwell will be at the ball to-night ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Probably .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I 'll see him . We 've always been good friends ,— and so were his father and your father . He wo n't let his firm make a scandal if he can help it , especially as they can gain nothing and we should lose so much ! Steve , we 'll get out of this yet , with your name all right !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Entering Right .May I come in ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , Bella .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , good evening , Mr. Carley , it 's a pleasant evening !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Good evening , Miss Shindle .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: What I come to ask is if I shall do you now , and Mrs. Wishings around the corner afterwards ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I think I 'd rather you went to Mrs. Wishings first if you do n't mind .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , it 's all the same to me ! Mrs. Wishings ai n't really in the smart set and they say her husband ai n't so rich , and she 's horrid to her servants — do n't give them cake . I do n't care if I lost her head to do ! I 'm like that , as you know , particular when I 'm particular , but — well — just supercilious and negligée when it do n't count ! Good gracious !Laughing .Oh , here 's a letter for you I brought up for Lizzie . It 's from the Phillypeenys and has a special delivery on .GEORGIANA takes letter and opens it and reads it .That 's how it come at this hour . Some folks do have luck , as the saying is ! I 've got to wait till to-morrow morning for mine if I get one , and if there 's a Phillypeeny post and I do n't get one , well , I pity the ladies ’ hair I dress to-morrow , that 's all !To STEVEN .Mr. Carley , you 've got lovely soft hair , have n't you ? I know you have a lovely disposition , I can tell it from your hair . Yes , indeed , they always go together , it 's a certain sign ! Now Mrs. Wishings ’ hair is just like a horse 's tail ! what there is of it . I often feel like asking her which she 'd rather I done it , on or off !Laughs heartily .I must have my little joke , but nobody minds me — good-by .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Good-by .

div.stage: BELLA goes out Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Looking up , bursting with happiness and reading as she speaks .Oh , Steve ! Steve ! Such good news ! I can hardly wait to tell you , but just let me finish it .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Finish anything that means good news , Georgy , and then for heaven 's sake tell me what it is .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Closing the letter .It 's finished !

div.stage: She looks up radiant and forgetful of him for a moment .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Well !

div.stage: Rises and goes to GEORGIANA .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Softly .Dick loves me !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Dick Coleman ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: He loves me , he 's always loved me !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But why —? I do n't understand —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , I did n't know it . I thought — there were reasons why I thought he did n't love me . But I understand now . Listen ; I 'll read you a part of his letter — a part of it ! Oh , this makes up for everything , Steve .She reads .“ My dear —She stops and improvises the next three words .my dear Georgy :She looks up slyly to see if Steven noticed the change ; he did n't .Each steamer brings me letters from home , but never a word of your engagement to Coast , never a word of your marriage . Is that broken off — ” How do you suppose he got the impression I was going to marry Sam ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Why everybody has seen , who cared to look , that Sam was dead in love with you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , but — well — never mind , listen — “ Well , however it is , we 're starting off to-morrow out of reach of letters and everything else , except an ugly band of natives that we came here to do for . The chances are pretty big against many of us getting back , and anyway I 'm going to take this chance to tell you that I love you better than anything and everything and everybody in the world . And in case I never come back , somehow or other , I do n't know why , I want you to know it . I was a little late in finding it out ,— all of a sudden I knew you were the only woman for me , and that the only thing I seemed to want in the world was you for a wife . And there was Coast ahead of me ! I do n't know if it would have made any difference if you loved Coast and not me , perhaps you never would have cared for me , but I 'd have done my best , for , Georgy — I love you ” —She reads ahead to herself , murmuring so he cannot understand .“ I do n't know why I must tell you all this , but I must ” —She reads ahead again in silence , skipping the passages which are too loving and too precious to read aloud .I think that 's all —She looks up and smiles , and adds softly .that I care to read aloud ! Oh , Steve !

div.stage: She puts her arms around his neck and hugs him .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'm so glad , old girl , so glad !

div.stage: Tightening his arm about her .

lg.l: Steve , I 'm so happy ! I do n't want to seem selfish , and really
I 'm not forgetting you , but I can n't help it . I 'm so happy .

div.stage: STEVEN kisses her . A short pause .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Softly , thoughtfully .Can one cable to the Philippines ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes !

div.stage: Smiling and again giving her a little squeeze .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Going to the sofa .So far as I 'm concerned , my money now does n't count a rap . Dick has plenty and does n't want mine . So now it 's only Louise and mother you must think of , and you can take care of them well , you know you can , if they 'll only accept the different conditions . And Dick and I 'll help —

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Interrupting .I hate to say it , Georgiana , but suppose —

div.stage: Very serious .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Well , you know why Dick wrote that letter ,— because he was going into dangerous fighting .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , he will come back , he must come back ! So few of our men have been lost in the Philippines , Dick can n't be one of the few . After all , life nowadays is n't so tragic as that .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , of course Dick 'll come back , GeorgyShort pause ., but wo n't he despise me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , you 're my brother . And oh , Steven , forgive me , but I 'm so happy .Hugging the pillows on the sofa and burying her face in them .Do n't let me be silly — do n't let me forget I 'm an old maid ,— and there 's no fool like an old fool ! I must n't forget there 's probably an orange or two among the blossoms for my hair !

div.stage: MRS. CARLEY and LOUISE come into the room from the Right without speaking . They look from GEORGIANA to STEVEN . They are under the strain of violent emotion almost too much for words . Their appearance is tragic . ] There is a pause .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Sam has told you ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: It is n't true what he says ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Bursting out , as the strain breaks .That everything 's gone ? Everything !

div.stage: MRS. CARLEY comes to STEVEN .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , it 's true !—

div.stage: He moves up .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: We have n't a cent ?— not a penny ! for car fare ! for theatre tickets ! nothing for our wash bills , or to go away with in the summer !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Georgiana 's money gone too — now , Steve ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: As well as Louise 's and mine ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , mine 's gone too now , but I 'm going to take it just as sensibly as Louise did before me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: She had yours to fall back on .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And I 'm going to take myself off your hands , and Steve is perfectly capable of getting some dignified position and taking care of you and Louise .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , I can imagine what that means ! A flat with rooms like a string of buttons , mantelpiece beds and divans ! and all your friends trying to get into the bathroom when they are looking for the hall door to get out !

div.stage: COAST comes in from the Right . They all look at SAM .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do you think Sam has a place here in what we may say now ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Why not ? He 's my cousin .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes . And the only one of us now anyway who has a cent .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I do n't think we can expect much help from Sam as to money .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That shows you do n't know me .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Going to COAST .You 'll help us ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 've offered to make up every cent Steve 's lost ; ask Georgiana .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , Sam offered to make a “ trade ” with me —

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: How ?

div.stage: Looks at GEORGIANA .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: To make up Steve 's losses if I 'd marry him .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Quietly to COAST .Sam ! It 's too good to be true .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: So Georgiana thinks .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Angrily .You wo n't do it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , I do n't love your cousin .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Do n't love him ! What do you owe us ? Louise loved Steve and what good did it do her ? You 've got the chance to make up for your brother !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: That 's not Georgiana 's duty ,— to make up for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: You can n't do it yourself , and you do n't want your wife to starve , do you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Louise wo n't starve .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: To GEORGIANA .You could save us and you wo n't !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I do n't love Sam .

lg.l: Do n't “ love ” ? Did Molly Packer from Toledo love the Duke of
Birmingham ? and is n't she happy now ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I do n't know , I have my doubts .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Doubts ! Oh , doubts !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's not the point , mother . I 'm not going to marry Sam .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Oh , very well , then , have your way .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I will , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Going to the sofa .Do n't consider my way at all .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I wo n't , mother , since you ask me not to .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: But I 'll tell you this , Georgiana , you 're just as bad as Steve ! We must shake off both of you . Louise must get a divorce and marry again . Look what other widows have done before her .

div.stage: Louise goes to her mother and takes her hand .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mother ! Louise !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Well , why not ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Certainly !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Goes to them .No ! Listen ! You must stand by Steve , both of you . You ought to do it out of affection , for , after all , whatever you 've got of friends and position and the things you value he gave you ! But never mind that ! You ought to stand by him out of loyalty ,— but never mind that ! You 've got to stand by him because if you ruin him you 'll ruin yourselves . You and mother could never hold up your heads again in our world — in the world you love — if you left Steve . After all , though our world may be careless sometimes of what it does itself , it is very particular about what those people do who are its guests ! Of course , Louise , it does come hardest on you , for yourself and for the children — but still you 've got to stand by Steve .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Sam !

div.stage: Going to SAM for help .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Oh , I suppose I 'll forgive him , I always do , but I do n't know about forgiving you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: If you do n't marry Sam ! You can make everything all right , and Sam loves you — you can make mother happy and me happy and Steve happy ....

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Interrupting .No , leave me out !

div.stage: He goes up behind the sofa .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Our life would go on just the same ,— Steve will make no more mistakes . I think you 're heartless to refuse !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But , Louise , you ask me to give up entirely my own happiness .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Not at all ! There 's no one else in love with you but Sam , and this is n't your first year out , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: And anyway it would be five happy against one unhappy , there 's no arguing about that .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: To LOUISE .You and your mother both think she ought to accept me , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: To GEORGIANA .I told you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , Sam , you win !— but Louise ! I love some one else .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Dick Coleman ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , and I 'm going to marry him .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Turning quickly .Has he asked you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes ! To-day !

div.stage: Showing her letter . MRS. CARLEY sits on the sofa .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Angry , to LOUISE .Then you bring suit against Steve and I 'll back you up ,— I 'll bet you I 'll get your case !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: But Steve has n't any money .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: No , but you can show him up ! You can blackguard his name for him ! You can disgrace him in the papers !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: But I do n't want to do that ! It would only make things worse .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good , Louise !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'll bet the bank and Steve 's brokers wo n't be so soft-hearted .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: There 's this house for the bank .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Crying .This house ! I shall die !

div.stage: GEORGIANA goes to her .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , no , you wo n't ; you 'll live very happily in a nice little flat , with two servants and a polite elevator boy in buttons .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Pitifully .Louise !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And Mr. Caldwell I am going to see at the ball to-night . I believe he will help us if he can .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: You 're going to the ball ? In spite of everything ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , we must . Let 's have as little talk about the whole thing as possible . Steve 's had bad luck ! The people must n't think there 's anything we 're ashamed of . There is n't anything .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , is n't there ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No .

div.stage: LOUISE gets the smelling salts from the table for MRS. CARLEY .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: It 's true ; so long as we 've lost everything else , I do n't see why she should lose the ball too !

div.stage: Using the smelling salts .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: And I suppose we really ought to be seen there , or lots of people will never believe we were asked .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , I guess this is where I get out . I 'll strike one of those musical comedies ! I think ragtime will be good enough for me to-night , instead of a neck and arm circus . You wo n't want me for escort after all this ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: You can please yourself , Sam .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Not exactly ; I guess this is the day I try sour grapes .Goes to door Left ,— he turns .When 's Coleman coming back , Georgiana ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh !Goes to STEVEN at mantel .Steve — listen — how long are they holding that rotten stock of yours for you ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Laughs .Ha ! till to-morrow noon .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , cheer up , I 'll send her up ten points for you by eleven .Slaps him on the back .See you all later , maybe , if my show 's dull .

div.stage: And with a side glance at GEORGIANA he goes out Left .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Rises .I only wish to heaven Sam Coast wanted to marry me !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Mother ! Come , let 's finish dressing .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I do n't know whether to go to the ball or stay home and have a good cry .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do whichever gives you the most pleasure , mother .

div.stage: LIZZIE enters Right and stands behind the dressing table .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: What ?Looking at herself in the glass .It 's all very well for them to give us women a new front , I wish they 'd give us new backs too .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: LIZZIE
sp.p: You must start dressing , miss — Miss Shindle will be back .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Absent-mindedly .Yes , yes , Lizzie .LIZZIE goes out .Louise , I 'm so glad you will stand by Steve ; and try and be glad a little for me .

div.stage: Placing her arm about LOUISE .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes , I do n't blame you , Georgy , so long as Dick 's proposed . I 'd do just as you 've done , and I will be glad for you by to-morrow ,— I am glad now .

div.stage: Kisses her impulsively .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Thank you , Louise , dear .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Louise !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Comes to STEVE .Steve .LOUISE touches STEVE on the arm .I do n't want to be horrid , but do you think you will be able to get anything decent to do ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'm sure I will .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: But will we have enough money to hold our own ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'll do my best . Louise , I appreciate your not making more of a row !

div.stage: With his arm around her .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Oh , Steve , I know it 's just as hard for you — and I do love you and I want to be nice about it , but —She cries . STEVEN kisses her again , in his arms .I must n't give way like this . I 'll be a sight at the ball . Do n't let me cry , dear .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: All right . Come on upstairs now , and make yourself beautiful .

div.stage: They go toward the door Right .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Reëntering Left .Good evening again , is Miss Georgiana ready for me ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: She must be ,— is my hair all right ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , yes , that 's one thing about my hair dressing , though I do say it as should n't , it has a lasting quality .

div.stage: LOUISE goes out Right .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Calls from inside .Is that you , Bella ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I 'll be there in a minute — be quick , Lizzie .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Lower voice .Mr. Carley , have you seen the evening papers ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I just bought one and it 's got an article about the 91st regiment .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: What about it ?

div.stage: Looks to see if door is closed .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Same voice .They say it may ‘ a ’ been wiped out of existence : it 's three weeks now since news of it was due , and the paper 's afraid they 've met with an ambyscade or something like that .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , when the newspapers are hard up for news they get up something about the Philippines ! It 's the modern sea-serpent . When there 's absolutely nothing else to print — no girl suicide in Brooklyn , or cyclone in Kansas , or joke on Chicago , then they give the Philippines a paragraph or an insurrection . Do n't you worry , Miss Shindle .

div.stage: He sits in the arm-chair near the sofa .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: But it says the island they went against was the heathenest of the lot , and that there 's no good reason why if they 'd had n't no fight with the natives , we should n't ‘ a ’ had news from them .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: The whole question of news in a case like this is too uncertain to make so much alarm about . The men 's idea is not to send picture postal cards of daily movements home to America , but to lick the natives into shape !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I 'm sure you do comfort me . Do n't know as Miss Georgiana told you , but my young man 's out there , with Mr .— Lieutenant Coleman .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Well , do n't worry . You just make up your mind the papers are short of news to-night .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Goodness , they wo n't be to-morrow with all they 're going to print about this ball ! Say , I 've a friend whose sister 's a literary lady and writes for the Sunday papers in Buffalo . She 's got an article in my line , called the “ Heads of the Smart Set which was Set at the Grand Duke . ” Ai n't that a cute name for an article ? And it do n't mean their heads either ; it means their coffyures , as she says — she speaks French . She was born and raised in Niagara Falls , near to Canada , where the language comes natural ,— over the water , as it were !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Going to her .I would n't mention this newspaper report to Miss Carley — it would only needlessly alarm her , perhaps , and spoil her evening .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , I would n't for worlds .

div.stage: She moves to the dressing table as GEORGIANA comes in .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Here I am ’ . Oh , my dear Steve ! You 'll be late . You 're not dressed yet .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: All right . I 'm going now — I was entertaining Miss Shindle till you were ready .

div.stage: With , a bow to MISS SHINDLE , STEVEN goes out Right .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Taking her bottles , etc ., from a little bag which she carries .He is a perfect gentleman !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sitting before the dressing table .Now come along , Bella ! I only want you to brush my hair ; I 've had a trying evening here , and I 've a splitting headache . See if you can take it away and make me look as if I 'd never had one .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Tying apron about GEORGIANA 'S neck .I 'll do my best ; but I can tell you most of the ladies I know 'd be willing to have a headache every blessed minute of their lives if they could look as you do now !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , what blarney , Bella ! I do n't know , somehow I want to be beautiful to-night .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: For the Dook ?

div.stage: Beginning to brush her hair .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: For him ?

div.stage: Pointing at COLEMAN 'S photograph with her hair-brush .

lg.l: Yes .
It was a dear letter
I had from him to-night , Bella ! I hope you 'll have as nice a one from
Mr. Gootch to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Well , if I do n't —

div.stage: Shutting her teeth , she unconsciously pulls GEORGIANA 'S hair .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Oh , oh !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't take it out on me , wait till Mr. Gootch gets back !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Combing .I do n't know as you 're the jealous kind . Judging from your hair you ai n't . It usually goes with blonde or red , or else crimpy , and what I dislike about red hair is the freckles — you can almost count on ‘ em ! You 've got sort of trusting hair . But besides , Mr. Coleman was n't a floor walker in a shop with over a hundred lady clerks — I think that 's apt to make a gentleman flightier ; and he being bald , has me to a disadvantage , so to speak . I can n't judge by my customary signs .

lg.l: Bella , I should say
Lieutenant Coleman has splendid , straight , honest hair , should n't you ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I can n't say as I 've ever really had any experience of his hair , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But do you think him an awfully handsome man , Bella , or am I prejudiced ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: No , indeed , I never seen a handsomer gentleman , not even in the pictures of gentlemen 's clothes in tailor store windows .Puts comb down , and takes brush and brushes again .But what continues to make me nervous about Mr. Gootch is that he 's right there among all those black creatures , whose manners is very free , I 'm told , and whose style of dressing is peculiar , the least you say ! Mr. Gootch always did favor dark-complexioned people , and if that letter do n't come to-morrow —

div.stage: Getting excited , she again pulls GEORGIANA 'S hair .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Ouch !Laughing , holds up her hand , and catches her hair to ward off another pull .Be careful !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Excuse me ! in my art , there 's no use talking , you ought n't let your mind wander from the subject in hand — does your head feel better ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I do n't know , Bella , if it does or not ! Your treatment is very heroic .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Spraying her hair .You do n't feel worried about something happening to them way out there , do you , Miss Georgiana ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I dare n't think of it . Oh , Bella , I 've had lots of trouble to-day , and I 've a serious time ahead of me — but all the same I am such a happy woman .Turning to look at BELLA , she disarranges her hair , much to BELLA 'S disapproval .Do you love Mr. Gootch tremendously , Bella ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Why , love is n't the word ! my feeling for Mr. Gootch is a positive worship . When I get to thinking of him in the underground I always go by my station , sometimes two .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Be grateful for your love , Bella ; it 's a wonderful thing .

lg.stage: Finishing the dressing of the hair .
lg.l: You know I 've just done
Mrs. Wishings , she puts too much on !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Does she rouge ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: No , hair . I do n't mind a switch or two for foundation , and a couple of puffs for ornament , with a tight curl or two for style ,— especially if you 've got one of those new undilated fronts , but I think that 's all you can expect to have any hair dresser make look as if it growed there . There ! How 's that ?

div.stage: Puts hairpin in GEORGIANA 'S hair .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Holding up DICK 'S photograph .How 's that , Dick — is it all right ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Delighted .Ai n't that a cute idea ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: We both trust you , Bella , to make me all right .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: What ornaments ?

div.stage: Taking off the apron , she walks around to Right of the table .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Would you wear any ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
