sp.p: Oh , yes , for such an occasion ! Of course , for maidens only feathers is correct ; for wives and widows , tiaras and feathers .

div.stage: Putting away her things . MRS. CARLEY enters in a flurry of excitement , superbly dressed , and too youthfully .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Here I am ; I 've hurried so I do n't feel half dressed .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Smiling .That 's almost the way you look , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Well , I always did have shoulders , and I do n't intend to hide them under a bushel ; but what do you think of the dress , is it a success ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: From your point of view — perfect !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , but what 's the difference about your point of view about it and mine ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Well , I should think about thirty years , darling !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Oh , Georgiana , you really are unkind . When I do n't know how on earth it 's ever going to be paid for now , I think you might be serious , and let me feel anyway it 's a success .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Mother dear , it 's a triumph . Really , I never saw you look better !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Really ! and how is my hair ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Redder !

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , Miss Georgiana , it is n't too red a bit .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: It 's very fine , Bella , but I think I 'd take off a little . You do n't want Mrs. Carley to rival Mrs. Wishings and look as if she 'd cornered the hair market .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: She 's just teasing you .

div.stage: GEORGIANA has risen .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: You are lovely , Georgiana .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That 's because my thoughts are lovely .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I 'm awfully proud of you , dear , and wish you were my own daughter .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Thank you , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: The Grand Duke will surely notice you . Are n't you going to put something in your hair ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Handing it to GEORGIANA .A rose with glass dewdrops .

div.stage: Newsboy 's voice heard in the street — calling , “ Extra — Extra — Terrible ” — the rest is indistinct .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: A newsboy with an extra .

div.stage: Man 's voice outside , “ Extra — Extra — Terrible ” — the rest is still indistinct . LOUISE enters , beautifully dressed .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Lovely , Louise !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I 've got a splitting headache .Man 's voice outside , “ Extra — Extra . ”What can the extra be ?Enter STEVEN .Steve , do you know what the extra is ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Oh , they 're never anything you know .

div.stage: In distance are heard several voices at once at different distances , all calling , “ Extra — Extra — Terrible ” — etc .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , they 're always so disappointing , generally a railway accident out west ! or a bomb thrown in Europe . Are you ready , Georgiana ?

div.stage: The “ Extras ” are louder .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , if we 're going we ought to go .

div.stage: “ Extra — Extra , ” called underneath the window .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Listen , what did he say ?

div.stage: Voice shouts outside , “ Terrible fight in the Philippines ; an entire regiment wiped out ! ”

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Frightened .I heard “ Philippines . ”

div.stage: Goes to the window .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: And a terrible fight ! Some one must get the paper !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: We have n't time now , Georgy .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes , we must be there before the Grand Duke arrives .

div.stage: Outside , “ Extra — Extra ! ”

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I must see that paper , Steve .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Georgiana , I think you are too thoughtless .

div.stage: Outside , “ Entire regiment wiped out ! ”

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Steve , do you hear that ! Will you get the paper or shall I call to the man ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I 'll get it .Goes to a window and opens it , pulling aside the curtain . He calls down to the boy in the street .Here ! Hi ! Extra !

div.stage: Voice outside , “ Here you are , boss ! ”

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Ring the bell .

div.stage: He comes back into the room . One “ Extra ” is heard louder than before , and then the cries gradually die away .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: The carriage has already been here nearly an hour .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: It if should be Dick 's fight , if it should be Dick 's regiment !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Make up your mind , mother , to be a little late . We can n't go till we see the paper .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: At the door Right .Lizzie ! Where is she ? Did n't he go to the door with the paper , Steve ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I 'll see , miss .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes . I saw him . But , Georgy , it wo n't be Dick 's regiment .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: By the sofa .Louise , I 'll tell you what we 'll do , let 's go down and be getting on our wraps .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No , mother , wait .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , Louise , go down , please , with mother . I 'd rather .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Going out Left .Yes , come along .

div.stage: LOUISE looks at GEORGIANA , who nods her head “ Yes ” to go .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: I 'll come back .

div.stage: She follows MRS. CARLEY out . LIZZIE enters Right with the paper . GEORGIANA takes the paper from LIZZIE , who immediately goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Shall I look ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Standing by the sofa .No , I will . Here it is — “ Battle with Ladrones . The 91st Regiment of New York , which went out under Captain H. S . Miller to subdue the bandits in the Island of Orla , met an ambuscade of the Ladrones and were annihilated almost to a man . ”She looks up dazed , not able at once to realize what it means . Rereads , skipping some lines .“ Captain H. S . Miller who went out under — to subdue the bandits in the — met an ambuscade of the Ladrones and was annihilated almost to a man . ” Steve ! his regiment ,— do you think it 's true ? Do you think it can be true ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Beside her .No , let me read it .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: She sinks down on the end of the sofa .No , I will !She reads on .“ News was brought by private — private —Her eyes hurrying on .the sole survivors . Privates — ”Her eyes run along the printed lines again .Steve , I can n't see his name . Is n't it there ? Ca n't you see it ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Looking .No .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Almost whispers .It means —?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Striving to hide his own emotion and to encourage her .The news is too meagre to be true .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: In hall Left .Georgiana ! We must go .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Starts . To STEVEN .Do n't let mother come in , please .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Just outside the door .Georgiana , we must go .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: To STEVEN .Say I 'm coming .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: I can n't leave you alone .Going to the door .Georgy 's coming .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Outside .Good ! Hurry !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Coming back to her .But I can n't leave you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You must . And anyway I want you to . I want to be alone .STEVEN hesitates . He comes and takes her hand and is about to kiss her , but something keeps him back ; he presses her hand and she gives a grateful look . She crosses to the dressing table and sits before it , dazed . Slowly she takes the flowers from her hair , the pearls from her neck . The front door slams , she lifts her head , and leaning her arm toward DICK 'S picture , draws it toward her , gazing at it . Then , crying , “ Dick , Dick , ” she bursts into tears and drops her head upon her arms outstretched on the table asTHE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT IV

stage.stage: Seven weeks later . The drawing-room as in Act II . GEORGIANA , in a clinging black lace dress , is at the piano , playing “ Traumerei . ” The sunshine pours in through the windows . MOLES comes in apologetically from the Left .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Mr. Coast wants to know if you will see him , miss .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Who continues playing .Very well , Moles .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Shall I show him up ?

div.stage: GEORGIANA nods her head . MOLES goes out . GEORGIANA continues playing . In a few seconds MOLES reënters with COAST .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Good morning , Georgiana .

div.stage: GEORGIANA , half smiling , bows very impersonally , and continues playing till she finishes the music . COAST leans against the piano , facing her , and watches her and waits .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: When she has finished .How long is it since you and I have been friends ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: It 's five weeks and a couple of days — but it was n't my fault .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Was n't it ? Well ? What is it ? Why do you want to see me ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Same reason as ever !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No ,— you would n't ask me that now !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes , I would !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , Sam ! Love is n't a game with all women , if you lose with one hand , to try another . Do you mean you think because Dick is dead , it would be any more possible for me to care for you ? I do n't respect you , Sam , and I do n't like you ,— and that 's putting it very politely ,— for many reasons ; but one 's enough — Steve !

div.stage: COAST looks away .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: After a second 's pause .I 've let you go on because I know I deserve all I get ; and I 've caught on to the fact that you wo n't ever care about me the way I want . Well , it 's funny , it do n't seem to make much difference in my feelings for you all the same !Half laughs .I ai n't exactly ashamed of what I 've done , but I 'm sort of sorry — for you .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Rising .I do n't want your sympathy , Sam .

div.stage: She comes away from the piano and he follows her .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Well , you 've got to get it , anyway ! That you can n't help , and if you can help loving me , you can n't help my loving you ! Anyway , I do n't want you to have to get out o ’ this house .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: That is all settled now ; we can n't afford to live here , of course .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Yes , you can .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No , no — Steve 's salary —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Steve 's leaving that job ; he do n't need that money any longer .

div.stage: He looks at her , she looks in his face — a short pause ; then —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You do n't mean you 've given Steve —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Do n't worry , I 'm giving away nothing . Steve 's got a new job .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I 'm going home — leastways so far 's Denver — and Steve 's going to look after my interests here .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Interrupting her .Oh , do n't worry — he can n't act without my advice — and that 's just the kind of a man I want ! I do n't want none of these here fellers who 's got judgment o ’ their own ! Steve 's knows he 's a fool in business , and he 'll obey me implicitly .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sitting by the table Left .And Steve is willing to accept from you —

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Interrupting .Oh , I guess he considers I owe him that much anyway .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: You could n't repay what you owe Steve .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: That 's how you look at it ! Then there 's Coleman 's money .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Do n't speak about that , please .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Why not ? he 's left it to you , everybody knows it , and it must be a good deal .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I can n't and wo n't discuss that with you .

lg.l: I wish you did n't feel so hard against me ,
Georgy !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: To tell you the truth , Sam , I do n't think I feel anything about you .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Oh , Lord , that 's worse ! I guess I wo n't stop at Denver ,— I 'll go away out to the mine for a while and join father .— Good-by .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good-by .

div.stage: Rises .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: I swore off a lot of things when I thought I was going to get you , Georgiana !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Without any feeling .I 'm glad !

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: But I do n't want to put on any bluff . I 've sworn ‘ em all on again .

div.stage: Going Left .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Same voice , without feeling .I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Turning quickly and with an absurd ray of hope .Are you really ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Looking at him a second .No , Sam , I suppose , if I tell the truth , I do n't really care . You see , somehow or other , I do n't care very much about anything .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Discouraged .Good-by .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good-by , a pleasant journey .

div.stage: She turns away . Coast is about to go when he meets LOUISE , who enters Left .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Good morning , Sam . Where are you off to ?

div.stage: Going to the sofa .

sp.speaker: COAST
sp.p: Chicago first , Lou , and then Denver , and eventually — hell , I guess !

div.stage: With a little gulp in his throat he goes out quickly .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: What 's the matter with him — he has n't proposed to you again ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: He 's going away , and he 's made Steve —

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Interrupting .I 've just seen Steve , he 's told me . Steve 's coming uptown soon — to see you —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sitting on the sofa beside LOUISE .To see me — why ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: He 'll tell you better than I — I feel happy , Georgiana .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I 'm glad .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: And I believe you 'll be happy again .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Thank you , Louise !

div.stage: MRS. CARLEY enters Right and sits by the table .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: You back , Louise ! I 'm that tired , shopping . I 'm buying everything I can think of we 'll be likely to need for months . There 'll be no pleasure buying things when , instead of having them sent to 2 East 71st Street , we have to say 329 West 143rd !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Rises and goes back of the table .Mother , dear , you may not have to leave here after all !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Louise will tell you . I 've promised to sit through lunch with the children this morning if you do n't mind , and it 's their hour .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: But , Georgiana —

div.stage: She is interrupted by a gesture and a glance from LOUISE to let GEORGIANA go .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Sweetly .Yes ? Do you want me for anything , dear ?

div.stage: LOUISE repeats the gesture , unnoticed by GEORGIANA .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Oh , no .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: If you want me —

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Louise , I told Bella Shindle I 'd help her get up an article this morning on the drawing-room and dining room for her sister ,— you know — who has a friend who writes for the weekly papers . You do n't mind , do you ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Of course , if you do mind —

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: But I do n't , not the least in the world .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Smiling .Bella says it will be a great thing for her sister 's reputation — what she calls such a “ select ” house as ours — and buy her a new hat besides . So I thought we 'd better .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Did you ever know any one so changed ? She has n't been horrid to me once since he died . It makes me feel perfectly dreadful to have her treat me so nice .

div.stage: Almost crying , crosses to Left .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Mother , you know Mrs. Coleman sent for me just now .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Well , why , do you suppose ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I do n't know , but I hope you 'll tell me that , too , sometime — what about Steve ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: That must wait , mother — Dick Coleman —

lg.l: What ? Do n't tell me he made another will , and did n't leave
Georgiana his money .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: No , it 's good news for Georgiana . I 'm almost as afraid to tell you as to tell her .Whispers .Dick Coleman may be alive , after all .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Louise !

lg.l: It is possible he was one of the three men who arrived at San
Francisco nearly a week ago .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Who were taken prisoners by the Ladrones and escaped ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes ! The three men who got away from Cebú in a boat and were picked up by a German steamer . It seems more than probable . They got one name wrong in the despatches , making it “ Richard Cotten ” — who was also missing — instead of “ Richard Coleman . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: But how did you find out all this ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: From Mrs. Coleman . And it 's all in the morning paper , and we never took the trouble to look !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: I read the society notes — it was n't in there .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Well , the Colemans saw it and telegraphed at once to Washington for confirmation .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Did they get it ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Not yet . But we 're all in the greatest hopes !

lg.l: But if Dick Coleman was with those other men in San
Francisco , why did n't he telegraph home ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: That 's the one thing that makes still a dreadful doubt .Rises and rings the bell .The Colemans are nearly mad waiting for their reply from Washington .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Shall you tell Georgiana ?

div.stage: She rises .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Not till we are a little more certain . It would be dreadful to open the wound of her grief again for nothing . Oh , if it 's only true !

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: And you 've seen Steve ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes , he went off at once to the newspaper to see how authentic their information was , and then he was going on to the Colemans .MOLES enters Left in answer to the bell .Moles , bring me the morning paper .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Unable to suppress his excitement .I 've read it , m 'm ! We 're all nearly crazy over it downstairs . Lizzie 's took to crying and can n't answer her bells .— Is it true , Mrs. Carley ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes , we hope it 's true , Moles .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Thank God , m 'm , if you 'll excuse me !

lg.l: But we 're not sure yet , and you must n't let anything drop before
Miss Georgiana till we are certain .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: No , m 'm .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Ought n't we to give Georgiana a hint to prepare her in some way ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Perhaps , if we do it very carefully .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: It seems awful to me not to tell her right out . Of course we wo n't have Dick Coleman 's money to help live on now , if he 's back .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Never mind that , mother .

div.stage: MOLES returns with the paper .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Here is the paper , m 'm , and Miss Shindle is come — she says to interview the drawing-room .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Very well — tell Miss Georgiana .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , m 'm .

div.stage: Goes out Right . LOUISE looks through the paper . MOLES brings in BELLA . BELLA shows signs of suppressed excitement .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Carley , have you seen the papers — is n't it splendid ?

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes , if it 's only true . We 're trying to make sure !

div.stage: LOUISE finds the place in the paper .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: Rising .She does n't know yet .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Carley !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: We 're waiting to be sure , and that we may be almost any minute .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Mercy ! I do n't see how you can keep it to yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. CARLEY
sp.p: You might give her a little hint , Bella , if you get a chance .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I would n't dare . If I opened my mouth wide enough to give her a hint , I know it would all burst out !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: As soon as Mr. Carley comes , make an excuse to leave her , wo n't you ? We expect him to bring us some definite news ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Yes , indeed !

div.stage: MRS. CARLEY and LOUISE go out Left , as GEORGIANA comes in .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Pleasantly .Good morning , Bella .

div.stage: She sits by the table .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Good morning , ai n't it a fine morning ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Is it ? I have n't been out .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I 'm scared to death .Laughing nervously .I ai n't going to write the article myself , you know . It 's my sister 's husband 's friend — she 's real literary enough ! She 's got a typewriter .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: One can n't do everything in this world , Bella , and you must be content with being a real artiste in your own profession .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Yes , I will say without boasting , so to speak , I do n't believe there 's a soul in New York who can make hair go further and wear less , than me !Laughs heartily .What 's this room ? Of course it 's one of them Louis , I suppose , ai n't it ?Looks around the room .Let me see , is it Louis Eleventimes ? I saw Henry Irving in that , it was fine !

lg.l: No , Bella , Henry Irving has never been in this room , and it 's
Louis XVI .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , of course !Writing .How well you 're looking , Miss Georgiana . Look to me kinder as if you thought good news was in the wind !

div.stage: She glances at her surreptitiously , but down again quickly , frightened .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Why , Bella ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , that 's just my idea , that 's all . What might this picture be ? Shall we say — er — er — Michael Ange ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Suppressing a smile .No , that is a Van Dyck .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Of course ! I might have known !Writing .This entire room is a fine bit , ai n't it ? All Louis —She looks back in her book .16 , as a piece , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: So I see ! My ! How I love all this kind of thing . I could n't live without a lot o ’ bric-a-brah lying around sort of careless like and undusted . These tapestries are real , I presume ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: I thought so ! I got a beautiful piece of tapestry over my washstand , hand-painted , and all the faces and clothes outlined in chenille cross-stitch by the Singer Sewing Machine — but it 's not quite the same as yours .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: It must be very pretty .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , it adds a touch ! Mr. Gootch gave it to me for an engagement present .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Does Mr. Gootch ever speak of Mr. Coleman ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: He worships him — naturally , as Mr. Coleman got wounded in both arms carrying him to a safe place ! Mr. Gootch says as there was n't a man in the regiment braver or as popular as Mr. Coleman . Do n't you think , perhaps , sometimes , maybe , Miss Georgiana —

div.stage: She stops near GEORGIANA .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Maybe what —?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , I dunno — I —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Rising and going to the sofa .Come , Bella , we must get on with your article .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Looking about .Why , you have n't got a cosy corner , have you ? And yet you seem to go in for the real artistic ! I do n't know what my sister ‘ n ’ I 'd do without our cosy corner ! It is draped with a fish net , and has paper butterflies and beetles in it ! Very artistic ! And she 's got — well , really now , I believe she 's got at least eleven pillers ; counting the two ticking ones that has their covers come off at night for our bed !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Rising nervously .Bella , I have some colored dresses I 'd like to give you for your trousseau , if you care to take them . They 've not been worn very much .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , Miss Georgiana , of course I 'd take ‘ em — only , I do n't know , I sort of feel it in my bones you 'll wear ‘ em yourself .

div.stage: STEVEN enters Left suddenly . He tries to conceal his great excitement . MOLES is with him .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: To MOLES .Tell Mrs. Carley I want to see her here , please .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: He goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Hello , Georgy !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Steve !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Good morning , Miss Shindle .

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Good morning , Mr. Carley . I must be going now , Miss Georgiana .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: But have you got enough for the article ?

sp.speaker: BELLA
sp.p: Oh , yes , miss — Louise furniture , the Van Wyck picture , tapestry effects — etcetra . Thank you ever so much . Good-by !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Wait , I 'll tell you about the dining room .

div.stage: She goes out with BELLA Left , and LOUISE enters .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Louise , it 's true !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Oh , Steve !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: It was a press telegram and has been verified by private wire . Besides , Mrs. Coleman has a telegram from Dick himself .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: From where ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: From San Francisco , when the Colemans were at Palm Beach . Their servants foolishly mailed the telegram to them , and before it arrived in Florida , they were on their way North , coming by easy stages .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Rises .And the message only just caught up with them ! Who will tell her ?

div.stage: MOLES comes in Left with a note .

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: A note just come for you , sir , by Mr. Coleman 's man .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: We must break it very gently , prepare her a little for it if we can .To MOLES .Thanks .Takes note , opens it , and reads it hurriedly .He 's there ! With his father and mother !

sp.speaker: MOLES
sp.p: Forgetting himself .Oh , sir — I 'm so glad ! Excuse me , sir , but we 're all so glad , sir — any answer sir ?

div.stage: His eyes fill up .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: No , only tell Miss Georgiana I want to see her .

lg.stage: Who has to swallow a lump in his throat before he can speak .
lg.l: Yes , sir .

div.stage: He goes out Right .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Wiping her eyes , goes to STEVEN .What does it say ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Reads the note .“ Dick and the answer from Washington arrived together ! ” He 'll be over here at once — they wo n't keep him .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: We must tell her before he gets here .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: We must do it very carefully .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: But we must n't lose any time .

div.stage: GEORGIANA comes in during this last speech , overhearing it . A movement is made by others on GEORGIANA 'S entrance .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: “ Losing time ! ” Am I keeping you from anything ? I 'm very sorry !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Very tenderly , and hiding her emotion .No , you 're not keeping us , Georgy , we only wanted to see you , that 's all .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Going to her .Why ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Also very tenderly .Do we have to have a reason to want to see you , is n't that we love you enough ?

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Yes , but why do you speak to me like this ?— it 's very kind of you — only — what does it mean ?

div.stage: Smiling a little nervously , they hesitate .

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Steve has news for you , Georgy .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: I know about it , Coast told me .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: It is n't that , Georgy .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: What is it , then ? How serious you both look .

div.stage: She becomes frightened .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: This is good news .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Good news !

sp.speaker: LOUISE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: The best in the world !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: For me ?

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: For you !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: A second 's pause , she speaks then in a low voice .No , it can n't be ! It can n't be !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Yes , it is , Georgy !

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Georgy ! It is !

div.stage: MOLES enters Left .

lg.stage: With voice full of happy emotion which he cannot disguise .
lg.l: Please , sir —

div.stage: He hesitates .

sp.speaker: STEVEN
sp.p: Show him here , Moles .

div.stage: MOLES lowers his head and goes out .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Dick —?

div.stage: She looks from STEVEN to LOUISE . They all show her by their faces and movements that it is true .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Whispers .Dick !

div.stage: She stands waiting , breathless . STEVEN steals out with his arm about LOUISE .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Excitedly , to herself .Come ! No , no ! It can n't be true ! It can n't be true ! They killed him , those brutes out there ! You told me so ! Every one believed it ! I believed it ! And so you want me to believe he 's alive ! That he 's here ! In this house , coming into this room — that I shall see —

div.stage: She stops suddenly , looking up . The door-knob of the door Left turns . Every nerve in GEORGIANA 'S body grows tense . MOLES opens the door and lets DICK pass in and closes the door behind him .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Cries out .Dick !

div.stage: DICK goes towards her , but stops . She starts towards him , stops a moment , and they look at each other , unable to speak ,— then she goes on slowly , almost fearfully , till she reaches him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Moving to her .Georgy !

div.stage: He stands before her with both arms bandaged in a sling .

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
sp.p: Whispers .Dick !Looks him straight in the eyes — he looks back . She cries out .Dick !

div.stage: Holding out her arms toward him .

sp.speaker: DICK
sp.p: Georgy !He looks down at his arms .My arms — I can n't —

sp.speaker: GEORGIANA
